parties.appellant: Robert P. Conlon and Betsy A. Conlon, Personal Representatives of the Estate of Michael Conlon (plaintiffs in the district court)
parties.appellee: Francis Scaltreto, Richard Benes, Glenn Chisholm, Dennis Dowling, Christopher Marzilli (officers, Newton Police Department), and City of Newton (defendants in the district court)

stage1_summary.factual_background: On January 5, 2021, Newton Police Department (NPD) responded to a report of an ongoing armed robbery at a candy store in Newton, Massachusetts. Officer Zachary Raymond arrived and saw Michael Conlon, a 28-year-old man with a mental illness that made him fear police, standing outside the store holding a small kitchen knife. Raymond drew his weapon and ordered Conlon to drop the knife. Conlon fled into his nearby apartment building, ascended to the third floor, and threatened to cut his own throat if Raymond advanced. Raymond retreated and waited for backup. Conlon knocked on a neighbor's door, asking to speak with someone who was not home. Additional NPD and Massachusetts State Police (MSP) officers arrived, including Captains Dennis Dowling and Christopher Marzilli, who recognized Conlon was experiencing a mental-health crisis. An NPD social worker was called to the scene. Officers assembled in the hallway and in Apartment 4, which was used as a staging area. The rear door to Apartment 3 was barricaded. Officer Francis Scaltreto negotiated with Conlon, who was holding the knife and a fire extinguisher, and eventually convinced him to drop both items after about twenty minutes. Officers had assured Conlon he would not be harmed. After Conlon dropped the items, Captain Dowling instructed Sergeant Glenn Chisholm to use a beanbag shotgun to incapacitate Conlon. Chisholm attempted to fire the beanbag shotgun from about twelve feet away, but it misfired. Some officers reported that Conlon then picked up the knife and moved toward Chisholm. An MSP trooper deployed a taser, and Officers Benes and Scaltreto fired their sidearms, fatally shooting Conlon. The Northeastern Massachusetts Law Enforcement Council's tactical team arrived six minutes later. An autopsy showed Conlon suffered fatal gunshot wounds to the head, neck, and torso.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs, as representatives of Michael Conlon's estate, sued the City of Newton and several NPD officers. They asserted claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 and the Massachusetts Civil Rights Act (MCRA) for excessive force, wrongful death under the Massachusetts Wrongful Death Act, and common law assault. Plaintiffs also brought claims against the City for failure to train and supervise under § 1983, and for violations of Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act, alleging failure to accommodate Conlon's disability and inadequate officer training.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss all claims for failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6), including on the basis of qualified immunity for the officers.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appeal the dismissal of their Fourth Amendment excessive force claim against the Officer-Defendants, the § 1983 claim against the City, the ADA and Rehabilitation Act claims, and the MCRA claim. Plaintiffs do not meaningfully challenge the dismissal of the wrongful death and common law assault claims.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing the § 1983 excessive force claim against the Officer-Defendants, including whether the officers are entitled to qualified immunity for their use of a beanbag shotgun and lethal force.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To state a Fourth Amendment excessive force claim under § 1983, plaintiffs must show a seizure occurred and that it was unreasonable. Qualified immunity shields officers unless they violated a clearly established right and an objectively reasonable officer would have known the conduct was unlawful.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing the § 1983 Monell claim against the City of Newton for failure to train and supervise officers.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Municipal liability under Monell requires a policy or custom attributable to the municipality, causation of the constitutional injury, and deliberate indifference by the municipality. Deliberate indifference typically requires a pattern of similar constitutional violations or that the need for training was so obvious as to constitute deliberate indifference.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing the ADA and Rehabilitation Act claims against the City for failure to accommodate Conlon's disability and for inadequate training.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To state a claim under Title II of the ADA or the Rehabilitation Act, plaintiffs must show that Conlon was a qualified individual with a disability, was denied the benefits of services or subjected to discrimination by a public entity, and that the denial or discrimination was by reason of his disability. Reasonable accommodation is required unless it would fundamentally alter the service or pose undue burden.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing the MCRA claim against the Officer-Defendants for use of excessive force.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The MCRA requires proof of interference with secured rights by threats, intimidation, or coercion, in addition to the underlying rights violation.

appellant_arguments: The officers used excessive force in violation of the Fourth Amendment, both in deploying the beanbag shotgun and in the fatal shooting, and are not entitled to qualified immunity.

The City of Newton failed to adequately train and supervise its officers regarding responses to mental health emergencies and use of beanbag shotguns, constituting deliberate indifference under Monell.
The City violated the ADA and Rehabilitation Act by failing to accommodate Conlon's mental health disability and by failing to provide adequate training to officers.
The officers' conduct constituted threats, intimidation, or coercion under the MCRA.
appellee_arguments: The officers are entitled to qualified immunity because their actions were reasonable under the circumstances and did not violate clearly established law.
The complaint fails to allege facts showing a municipal policy or custom, or deliberate indifference by the City, as required for Monell liability.
The ADA and Rehabilitation Act claims fail because the officers' actions were not discriminatory by reason of disability, and the City provided some training and accommodations.
The MCRA claim fails because allegations of excessive force alone do not constitute threats, intimidation, or coercion as required by the statute.

issue_1.reasoning: On a motion to dismiss, the court must accept all well-pleaded facts as true and draw all reasonable inferences in the plaintiff's favor. The complaint alleges that Conlon had dropped his weapons after assurances he would not be harmed, and that officers then used a beanbag shotgun and, after a misfire, lethal force. These facts plausibly allege that the force used was unreasonable under the Fourth Amendment, especially given Conlon's mental health crisis and the officers' knowledge of it. The question of qualified immunity is fact-intensive and, at the pleading stage, dismissal is generally inappropriate unless the unlawfulness of the conduct was not clearly established. Here, the complaint plausibly alleges a violation of clearly established law regarding use of deadly force against an unarmed, non-threatening individual. Thus, the district court erred in dismissing the excessive force claim and granting qualified immunity at this stage.

issue_2.reasoning: To state a Monell claim, plaintiffs must allege a municipal policy or custom and deliberate indifference. The complaint does not allege a pattern of similar incidents or facts showing that the need for training was so obvious as to constitute deliberate indifference. General allegations of inadequate training, without more, are insufficient. The district court properly dismissed the Monell claim for failure to state a claim.

issue_3.reasoning: The ADA and Rehabilitation Act require that the denial of benefits or discrimination be 'by reason of' disability. The complaint does not plausibly allege that the officers' actions were motivated by Conlon's disability, or that a reasonable accommodation was feasible under the rapidly evolving, dangerous circumstances. The officers called a social worker and attempted negotiation, indicating some accommodation. The district court correctly dismissed these claims.

issue_4.reasoning: The MCRA requires threats, intimidation, or coercion in addition to the underlying rights violation. Massachusetts courts have held that excessive force alone does not satisfy the 'threats, intimidation, or coercion' element unless there is evidence of coercion independent of the force itself. The complaint does not allege such independent coercion. The district court properly dismissed the MCRA claim.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The excessive force claim against the officers should survive a motion to dismiss because the complaint plausibly alleges an unreasonable use of force and the inapplicability of qualified immunity at the pleading stage. However, the Monell, ADA/Rehabilitation Act, and MCRA claims are insufficiently pleaded under controlling law and were properly dismissed. This results in a mixed outcome: reversal as to the excessive force claim, and affirmance as to the others.

parties.appellant: Ramón González-Beiró, Secretary of the Puerto Rico Department of Agriculture; Alex Muñiz-Lasalle, Deputy Secretary of the Puerto Rico Department of Agriculture (defendants)
parties.appellee: Northwestern Selecta, Inc. (plaintiff)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Northwestern Selecta, Inc. (NWS) is a company based in San Juan, Puerto Rico, that imports fresh and frozen poultry products from the continental United States and abroad. The poultry products at issue are shipped by sea in large cargo containers and enter Puerto Rico via the Port of San Juan. All poultry products imported by NWS from the mainland United States are inspected by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) prior to transport and are marked as officially inspected. Upon arrival in Puerto Rico, the containers are offloaded at the port and await clearance from authorities, including the Puerto Rico Department of Agriculture (PRDA). NWS provides the PRDA with bills of lading for the shipments, which indicate the contents but not their condition upon arrival. Once cleared, a contractor transports the containers to NWS's facility, where they are opened and unloaded. In June 2016, the PRDA promulgated Market Regulation No. 8, which governs the quality and marketing of poultry meat in Puerto Rico. Article XII(B) of this regulation requires a PRDA inspector to be present when a shipping container transporting poultry meat is opened and unloaded. For about five years after the regulation was enacted, the PRDA did not enforce Article XII(B) against NWS. In June 2021, the PRDA began issuing detention orders against NWS for opening and unloading containers without a PRDA inspector present, impounding over 200,000 pounds of poultry and issuing violation notices for thirty-five containers, with potential fines totaling approximately $263,000.

procedural_history.claims_brought: NWS filed a verified complaint in federal court, asserting that Article XII(B) (the inspector presence requirement) and Article XIV(A)(6) (a labeling provision) of Market Regulation No. 8 were expressly preempted by the federal Poultry Products Inspection Act (PPIA) and its implementing regulations. NWS sought declaratory and injunctive relief.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted NWS's emergency motions for preliminary and then permanent injunctions, declaring that the PPIA expressly preempts Article XII(B) and enjoining its enforcement against NWS. The court also granted relief regarding Article XIV(A)(6), but the PRDA did not appeal that ruling.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The PRDA appeals the district court's determination that the PPIA expressly preempts Article XII(B) of Market Regulation No. 8 and the resulting permanent injunction against its enforcement.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the Poultry Products Inspection Act (PPIA) expressly preempts Article XII(B) of Market Regulation No. 8, which requires a PRDA inspector to be present when a shipping container transporting poultry meat is opened and unloaded at NWS's facility.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Interpretation of the PPIA's express preemption clause (21 U.S.C. § 467e), which prohibits states or territories from imposing requirements with respect to premises, facilities, and operations of any official establishment that are in addition to, or different than, those made under the PPIA, subject to a savings clause allowing concurrent jurisdiction over articles outside of an official establishment for the purpose of preventing distribution of adulterated or misbranded products.

appellant_arguments: The district court interpreted the term 'operations' in the PPIA's preemption clause too broadly; 'operations' should be limited to slaughtering and processing activities, not distribution or unloading.

Article XII(B) does not directly affect the operations of NWS's facility, as it does not regulate the conditions under which NWS can process, receive, handle, package, or market meat, but only requires inspector presence during unloading.
The savings clause of the PPIA allows the Commonwealth to exercise concurrent jurisdiction in this context, and Article XII(B) is a permissible exercise of that authority.
The district court misapplied the statutory context and the PPIA's regulatory scheme by failing to recognize that the PPIA does not regulate matters unrelated to slaughter or processing.
appellee_arguments: Article XII(B) is expressly preempted by the PPIA because it imposes an additional requirement on the operations of an official establishment, which is not found in the PPIA or its regulations.

The ordinary meaning of 'operations' in the preemption clause includes the activities of opening and unloading containers at the facility, and Article XII(B) directly affects NWS's distribution operations by causing delays and reducing shelf-life.
The savings clause does not apply because Article XII(B) regulates activities inside the official establishment, not outside, and thus is not a permissible exercise of concurrent jurisdiction.

The PPIA and its implementing regulations cover a broad range of activities beyond slaughtering and processing, including distribution, labeling, and quality control, so the preemption clause should be interpreted broadly.

issue_1.reasoning: The question of whether the PPIA expressly preempts Article XII(B) is a pure question of statutory interpretation, reviewed de novo. The PPIA's preemption clause (21 U.S.C. § 467e) prohibits states from imposing requirements with respect to the 'premises, facilities, and operations' of any official establishment that are in addition to or different from federal requirements. The ordinary meaning of 'operations' is broad and, as the appellee argues, includes the activities of opening and unloading containers at the facility, especially since these are integral to the distribution and handling of poultry products. The PRDA's requirement that a local inspector be present during unloading imposes an additional operational requirement not found in the PPIA or its regulations. The savings clause does not apply because the regulation targets activities inside the official establishment, not outside. Federal courts and the USDA have interpreted the PPIA's preemption clause broadly to cover a wide range of activities at official establishments, including those related to receiving and handling product. Therefore, the district court correctly concluded that Article XII(B) is expressly preempted.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The legal question is straightforward and the district court's reasoning aligns with the text and purpose of the PPIA, as well as with precedent interpreting federal preemption in the context of food safety and inspection. The PRDA's arguments for a narrow reading of 'operations' are unpersuasive given the statutory language and regulatory context. The savings clause does not save Article XII(B) because it does not regulate activities outside the official establishment. The appellate court is likely to affirm the district court's ruling.

parties.appellant: Dahua Technology USA, Inc., plaintiff in the district court
parties.appellee: Feng Zhang, defendant in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background: Dahua Technology USA, Inc. is a U.S. subsidiary of Zhejiang Dahua Technology Co., Ltd., a Chinese surveillance technology company. In January 2016, Feng Zhang became an executive at Dahua, serving as Chief Strategy Officer, Vice President, and President of North American and Enterprise Sales. Zhang's employment terms were set in a 2015 Employment Agreement, which included a one-time stock grant and an annual base salary of $510,000 for three years, with the salary 'conditionally guaranteed' even if terminated for cause (except for illegal conduct or company misconduct). In mid-2017, Zhejiang's board decided to remove Zhang from management, concerned about potential liability for early termination and the lack of restrictive covenants preventing Zhang from disclosing sensitive company information. Negotiations between Zhang and Zhejiang's chairman, Liquan Fu, led to discussions about Zhang stepping down and taking a new role. Initial drafts of separation and consulting agreements were rejected by Zhang as not reflecting the discussions. Subsequently, two new agreements were prepared: a Release Agreement (including a severance provision and restrictive covenants) and a 2017 Employment Agreement (offering Zhang a Senior Corporate Advisor role at $240,000 per year). The Release Agreement stated that Dahua would make 'monthly severance payments to you in the amount of $680,000 for sixteen (16) months.' Both agreements were signed by Zhang and Fu. After Zhang began his new role, Dahua paid him according to his previous salary and the new advisor salary. In January 2018, Dahua terminated Zhang and offered a new separation agreement with a lower severance amount, which Zhang refused. Zhang demanded the severance as stated in the Release Agreement. Dahua claimed a scrivener's error in the Release Agreement and sought to amend it, but Zhang refused.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Dahua filed suit under diversity jurisdiction, seeking reformation of the Release Agreement's severance provision and alleging breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Dahua claimed the severance provision contained a scrivener's error resulting from mutual mistake, and sought to reform the contract to provide for a total severance of $680,000 paid over sixteen months. Zhang counterclaimed for breach of contract, asserting Dahua failed to pay the severance as written.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court initially granted summary judgment for Dahua, finding a mistake in the severance provision and ordering reformation. On appeal, the First Circuit vacated the summary judgment, finding disputed material facts regarding mistake. On remand, after a bench trial, the district court found that both parties were mistaken about the severance amount but concluded that, under Massachusetts law, the contract could not be reformed or rescinded due to Dahua bearing the risk of mistake. The court enforced the agreement as written and entered judgment for Zhang on his breach of contract counterclaim, awarding $10,200,000 plus prejudgment interest.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Dahua appeals the district court's rulings, specifically challenging the interpretation of the severance provision as unambiguous, the denial of reformation or rescission, and the judgment for Zhang on the breach of contract counterclaim. Dahua also appeals the rejection of its claim for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in concluding that the severance provision in the Release Agreement unambiguously required Dahua to pay Zhang $680,000 per month for sixteen months, rather than a total of $680,000 paid over sixteen months.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Massachusetts law, a contract is ambiguous if the language is reasonably susceptible to more than one interpretation. The interpretation of a contract is a question of law for the court. If ambiguous, extrinsic evidence of the parties' intent may be considered.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in denying Dahua's claim for reformation or rescission of the Release Agreement based on mutual or unilateral mistake.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Reformation under Massachusetts law requires clear demonstration of a prior, express agreement to which the written contract can be reformed. Rescission for mistake requires a material mistake not borne by the party seeking relief. The Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 152 and § 155 are relevant.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in rejecting Dahua's claim that Zhang breached the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing by refusing to amend the Release Agreement.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing is limited to the scope of the contract and does not impose duties beyond the express terms of the agreement.

appellant_arguments: The severance provision is ambiguous and should be interpreted in light of extrinsic evidence, which shows the parties intended a total severance of $680,000 paid over sixteen months.
The district court should have allowed reformation or rescission of the Release Agreement due to mutual or unilateral mistake, as the written contract did not reflect the parties' true agreement.
Zhang breached the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing by refusing to correct the scrivener's error in the Release Agreement.
appellee_arguments: The severance provision is unambiguous and requires payment of $680,000 per month for sixteen months, as written.
There was no prior express agreement to support reformation, and Dahua bore the risk of any mistake as the drafter of the agreement.
Zhang had no contractual or implied duty to agree to amend the Release Agreement, and his refusal does not constitute a breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.

issue_1.reasoning: Interpretation of contract language is a question of law reviewed de novo. The district court found the severance provision unambiguous, requiring $680,000 per month for sixteen months. The language is clear and not reasonably susceptible to the alternative interpretation Dahua proposes. The court is likely to affirm, as the plain language controls and extrinsic evidence is not considered when the contract is unambiguous.

issue_2.standard_of_review: clear error (factual findings), de novo (legal conclusions)
issue_2.reasoning: The district court found both parties were mistaken but concluded Dahua bore the risk of mistake as the drafter and failed to show a prior, express agreement for reformation. Under Massachusetts law and the Restatement, reformation is not available without a clear prior agreement, and rescission is unavailable where the party seeking relief bears the risk. These are mixed questions, but the district court's findings are well-supported and consistent with law. Affirmance is likely.

issue_3.reasoning: Whether the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing was breached is a legal question. The covenant does not require a party to amend a contract or go beyond its express terms. Zhang's refusal to amend the agreement does not constitute a breach. The district court correctly rejected this claim.

stage2_decision.reasoning: All issues are governed by well-settled Massachusetts contract law. The contract language is unambiguous, Dahua as drafter bore the risk of mistake, and there is no basis for reformation, rescission, or breach of the implied covenant. The district court's findings and conclusions are well-supported and likely to be affirmed in full.

parties.appellant: Govanni R. Nunez, plaintiff in the underlying action
parties.appellee: Commissioner of Social Security, defendant in the underlying action

stage1_summary.factual_background: Govanni R. Nunez previously worked full time as a security guard for the New York Public Library. He attended special education classes through the fifth grade and dropped out due to instability at home. In 2013, at age 35, Nunez experienced his first panic attack while riding the subway to work. Since then, he has suffered from panic symptoms, especially in enclosed spaces and on public transportation. His panic attacks last 5 to 20 minutes and include symptoms such as tachycardia, palpitations, cold sweats, nausea, shortness of breath, and tingling in his extremities. Nunez began treatment for anxiety and panic attacks in at least November 2016, initially responding well to Lexapro, but his symptoms returned after discontinuing the medication. By August 2018, despite resuming Lexapro, Nunez continued to experience panic attacks at work, sometimes requiring him to leave his post. His anxiety medications caused drowsiness, leading him to fall asleep during shifts. On August 22, 2018, he was terminated from his job due to frequent panic attacks. Nunez was also prescribed Atarax for acute panic attacks, which he took three to four times daily, causing significant drowsiness. He reported having two or three good days per week, during which he could perform chores, go for short walks, attend church, or visit family (with assistance for transportation). His panic attacks and medication side effects limited his ability to function on other days.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Nunez filed for Supplemental Security Income and Social Security Disability Insurance on September 9, 2018, alleging disability due to mental health conditions (primarily anxiety and panic disorder) with an onset date of August 22, 2018. The Social Security Administration (SSA) denied his claims on December 24, 2018. Nunez appealed to an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ).
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The ALJ held a hearing on August 14, 2019, and ultimately found that Nunez was not disabled under the Social Security Act, determining that he had a moderate limitation in concentrating, persisting, or maintaining pace, but that he retained the residual functional capacity (RFC) to perform certain unskilled work. The ALJ's decision became final after the Appeals Council denied review. Nunez then filed suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, which granted judgment on the pleadings in favor of the Commissioner, affirming the denial of benefits.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Nunez appeals the district court's judgment, specifically challenging the ALJ's determination of his residual functional capacity and the finding that he was not disabled.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the ALJ's determination of Nunez's residual functional capacity (RFC) was supported by substantial evidence, particularly regarding limitations in his ability to stay on task and maintain regular work attendance.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The ALJ's findings must be supported by substantial evidence, meaning relevant evidence that a reasonable mind might accept as adequate to support a conclusion. The ALJ must also apply the correct legal standards, including proper evaluation of medical opinions under 20 C.F.R. § 404.1520c, which requires consideration of supportability and consistency.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the ALJ properly evaluated the medical opinions in the record, including those of Nunez's treating psychiatrist and consultative examiners, in determining the RFC.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: For claims filed after March 27, 2017, the ALJ must evaluate the persuasiveness of each medical opinion based primarily on supportability and consistency (20 C.F.R. § 404.1520c). The ALJ must articulate how these factors were considered for each medical source.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the ALJ properly considered Nunez's subjective testimony and self-reported symptoms in assessing his functional limitations.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The ALJ must consider the claimant's subjective complaints and credibility, but may discount them if not supported by the record. The ALJ's credibility determination must be supported by substantial evidence and set forth with sufficient specificity.

appellant_arguments: The ALJ failed to support the RFC determination with substantial evidence, particularly by not including limitations related to Nunez's ability to stay on task and maintain regular attendance, despite uncontroverted vocational expert testimony and unanimous medical opinions indicating such limitations.

The ALJ improperly rejected or discounted the opinions of Nunez's treating psychiatrist and other medical sources, which consistently found moderate or greater limitations in his ability to sustain an ordinary work routine and regular attendance.
The ALJ failed to provide adequate reasons for discrediting Nunez's subjective testimony and self-reported symptoms, which were consistent with the medical evidence.
appellee_arguments: The ALJ's RFC determination was supported by substantial evidence in the record, including evidence of Nunez's improvement with treatment, ability to perform daily activities, and the consultative examiner's findings.
The ALJ properly evaluated the medical opinions, considering their supportability and consistency with the overall record, and was not required to adopt any particular opinion in full.
The ALJ reasonably assessed Nunez's subjective complaints in light of the objective medical evidence and his reported activities, and was entitled to discount testimony not supported by the record.

issue_1.reasoning: The record indicates that all medical sources, including Nunez's treating psychiatrist and consultative examiners, found moderate or greater limitations in his ability to sustain a work routine and regular attendance. The ALJ did not adequately account for these limitations in the RFC, nor did the ALJ address uncontroverted vocational expert testimony that such limitations would preclude competitive employment. The ALJ's RFC finding thus lacks substantial evidence and does not reflect the record as a whole.

issue_2.reasoning: The ALJ was required to evaluate the persuasiveness of each medical opinion based on supportability and consistency, and to articulate how these factors were considered. Here, the ALJ discounted the treating psychiatrist's and other medical sources' opinions without sufficient explanation or analysis of supportability and consistency, contrary to 20 C.F.R. § 404.1520c. This failure constitutes legal error and is not harmless, as it affected the RFC determination.

issue_3.reasoning: The ALJ discounted Nunez's subjective complaints and self-reported symptoms without providing adequate reasons or specific findings, despite their consistency with the medical evidence. The ALJ's credibility determination is not supported by substantial evidence and lacks the required specificity.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The ALJ's decision is undermined by a failure to properly evaluate and articulate the persuasiveness of medical opinions, to support the RFC with substantial evidence, and to adequately consider the claimant's subjective complaints. The record shows consistent findings of limitations that were not reflected in the RFC, and the ALJ did not provide sufficient reasoning for discounting this evidence. These errors are not harmless and require remand for further proceedings.

parties.appellant: Jessica Silveira da Silva, respondent in the district court
parties.appellee: Edervaldo Rodrigues da Silva, petitioner in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background: Jessica Silveira da Silva and Edervaldo Rodrigues da Silva, both citizens and natives of Brazil, married in 2011 and had a son, A.R., about three years later. The couple separated in 2016, with Silveira remaining A.R.'s primary caretaker. Rodrigues visited A.R. about two weekends per month. In 2021, Silveira began a relationship with Gilberto Lucas, who later immigrated to the United States. Silveira and Rodrigues legally divorced in December 2021, agreeing to share custody of A.R., who would continue to live with Silveira. In early 2022, Silveira expressed a desire to travel to the United States with A.R. Rodrigues signed a passport application for A.R., but later became suspicious that Silveira intended to permanently relocate. He attempted to cancel A.R.'s passport, but Silveira and A.R. left Brazil around March 28, 2022, traveling through Colombia and Mexico before entering the United States on April 3, 2022. Silveira and A.R. settled in Lowell, Massachusetts, living with Lucas and his extended family. Silveira applied for asylum in the United States. Rodrigues, upon learning of their departure, filed a police report in Brazil and later confirmed their location in Lowell. A.R. and Rodrigues now communicate via video calls about three times a week. In Lowell, A.R. has lived with Silveira and Lucas, attended the same elementary school, and participated in community activities such as church and soccer. He has developed relationships with Lucas's family and has made friends, particularly within the Brazilian community. Both Silveira and Lucas have steady employment.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Rodrigues initiated proceedings in federal court under the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and the International Child Abduction Remedies Act (ICARA), seeking the return of A.R. to Brazil. Silveira raised several affirmative defenses under the Hague Convention, including the 'now settled' defense, the 'consent' exception, and the 'grave risk' exception.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court held a three-day bench trial, found that Rodrigues had established a prima facie case of wrongful removal, and rejected all three of Silveira's affirmative defenses, including the 'now settled' defense. The court ordered Silveira to make arrangements to return A.R. to Brazil.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Silveira appeals the district court's rejection of the 'now settled' defense, specifically challenging the court's analysis and conclusion that A.R. is not settled in the United States.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court misapplied the legal standard for the 'now settled' defense by engaging in a comparative analysis between A.R.'s life in the United States and his life in Brazil.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The 'now settled' defense under the Hague Convention allows a court to decline to order the return of a child if the respondent proves by a preponderance of the evidence that the petition for return was filed more than one year after the wrongful removal and that the child is now settled in the new country. The determination is made under a totality-of-the-circumstances standard, considering factors such as the child's age, stability and duration of residence, school attendance, relationships with friends and relatives, community involvement, financial stability, and immigration status.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court clearly erred in its factual findings and weighing of the evidence in concluding that A.R. was not 'now settled' in the United States.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Factual findings by the district court are reviewed for clear error. The 'now settled' determination is based on whether the child has significant connections demonstrating a secure, stable, and permanent life in the new environment, assessed under the totality of the circumstances.

appellant_arguments: The district court misapplied the legal standard for the 'now settled' defense by improperly comparing A.R.'s life in the United States to his life in Brazil, rather than focusing solely on whether A.R. is settled in the United States.

The district court clearly erred in its factual findings and in weighing the evidence, as the record demonstrates that A.R. is settled in the United States based on his stable residence, school attendance, family and community ties, and overall integration.
appellee_arguments: The district court correctly applied the legal standard for the 'now settled' defense and properly considered the relevant factors under the totality of the circumstances.

The district court's factual findings are supported by the record, including evidence of A.R.'s relatively recent relationships in the United States, challenges in school adjustment, and limited duration and depth of community involvement.

issue_1.reasoning: The appellate court reviews the district court’s application of the legal standard de novo. While the appellant argues that the district court improperly engaged in a comparative analysis between A.R.'s life in the U.S. and Brazil, the summary does not indicate that the district court relied on an impermissible comparison as the basis for its decision. Rather, the court appears to have considered the totality of the circumstances, as required. Unless the record shows the district court fundamentally misunderstood or misapplied the legal standard, the appellate court is likely to affirm.

issue_2.reasoning: Factual findings regarding whether A.R. is 'now settled' are reviewed for clear error, a highly deferential standard. The district court considered evidence of A.R.'s relatively short time in the U.S., the recency of his relationships, and possible adjustment issues. Even if there is evidence supporting the appellant’s view, the appellate court will not reverse unless left with a definite and firm conviction that a mistake was made. The record supports the district court’s findings, so clear error is not shown.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Both issues on appeal are subject to deferential standards (de novo for legal standard, clear error for factual findings). The district court appears to have applied the correct legal standard and made factual findings supported by the record. The appellant’s arguments do not demonstrate a misapplication of law or clear error in fact-finding. Therefore, the appellate court is likely to affirm the district court’s rejection of the 'now settled' defense and its order for A.R.'s return to Brazil.

parties.appellant: David Monk, Lead Plaintiff (minority shareholder, tendered shares in merger)
parties.appellee: Shanda Games Limited, Yingfeng Zhang (former CEO), Li Yao (former CFO), Lijun Lin, Heng Wing Chan, Yong Gui, Shaolin Liang, Danian Chen (directors) (Defendants)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Shanda Games Limited, a Cayman Islands-registered video game company with American Depository Shares (ADS) listed on NASDAQ, developed a successful online game, Mir II, and later a mobile version, MIIM. In 2015, Shanda's board, including its CEO and other directors, participated in a freeze-out merger (the 'Freeze-Out Merger') in which a buyer group, comprised of insiders and controlling shareholders, acquired the company and cashed out minority shareholders at $7.10 per ADS. The merger occurred shortly after the successful launch of MIIM, which generated significant revenue. As part of the merger process, Shanda issued two proxy statements (the 'Proxies') to shareholders, representing the merger as fair and relying on financial projections prepared by management. Plaintiffs allege that these projections underestimated Shanda's financial prospects, particularly MIIM's revenue, and that the Proxies omitted or misrepresented material information, thereby discouraging minority shareholders from exercising their appraisal rights. An appraisal action in the Cayman Islands later determined the merger price was only 55% of the fair value of the shares.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs, on behalf of a putative class of similarly situated investors, brought claims under §§ 10(b), 20A, and 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, alleging that Shanda and individual defendants made material misstatements and omissions in connection with the Freeze-Out Merger, causing financial loss by inducing shareholders to accept the merger price instead of exercising appraisal rights. Insider trading claims were also included but are not at issue in this appeal.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The United States District Court for the Southern District of New York (Carter, J.) dismissed the claims against Shanda and the individual defendants for failure to state a claim, specifically finding that Monk failed to adequately plead loss causation. The court previously found that Monk could invoke the fraud-on-the-market presumption for reliance but concluded that the complaint lacked sufficient allegations explaining how Monk was personally induced to forfeit his appraisal rights. The court also denied leave to add Altimeo Asset Management as an additional named plaintiff.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Monk appeals the dismissal of his securities fraud claims for failure to state a claim, specifically challenging the district court's conclusions on loss causation, the actionability of certain alleged misstatements and omissions, and the denial of leave to add Altimeo Asset Management as a plaintiff.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in holding that Monk failed to adequately plead loss causation in connection with his § 10(b) securities fraud claim.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To plead loss causation, a plaintiff must allege a causal connection between the alleged misconduct and the economic harm suffered, i.e., that the subject of the fraudulent statement or omission was the cause of the actual loss. (Lentell v. Merrill Lynch & Co., 396 F.3d 161, 172 (2d Cir. 2005); Castellano v. Young & Rubicam, Inc., 257 F.3d 171, 186 (2d Cir. 2001)).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Monk adequately pleaded actionable material misstatements or omissions in the Proxies regarding the fairness of the merger, the financial projections, and the omission of MIIM revenue information.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A statement is actionable under § 10(b) if it is a material misrepresentation or omission. For statements of opinion, liability attaches if the speaker did not believe the opinion, the supporting facts were untrue, or the statement omitted information making it misleading to a reasonable investor. (Omnicare, Inc. v. Laborers Dist. Council Const. Indus. Pension Fund, 575 U.S. 175 (2015); Tongue v. Sanofi, 816 F.3d 199 (2d Cir. 2016)).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Monk adequately pleaded scienter as to Shanda and the individual defendants.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Scienter requires an intent to deceive, manipulate, or defraud, which may be established by showing that defendants had both motive and opportunity to commit fraud, or strong circumstantial evidence of conscious misbehavior or recklessness. (Tellabs, Inc. v. Makor Issues & Rights, Ltd., 551 U.S. 308 (2007); Kalnit v. Eichler, 264 F.3d 131 (2d Cir. 2001)).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Monk may invoke the fraud-on-the-market presumption to satisfy the reliance (transaction causation) element in the context of a freeze-out merger.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The fraud-on-the-market presumption applies if the alleged misrepresentations were public, material, the stock traded in an efficient market, and the plaintiff traded the stock between the time of the misrepresentation and the truth being revealed. (Basic Inc. v. Levinson, 485 U.S. 224 (1988); Halliburton Co. v. Erica P. John Fund, Inc., 573 U.S. 258 (2014)).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion in denying leave to amend the complaint to add Altimeo Asset Management as a named plaintiff.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Leave to amend should be freely given when justice so requires, unless there is a valid reason such as futility, undue delay, or prejudice. (Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(a); Panther Partners Inc. v. Ikanos Comm’n, Inc., 681 F.3d 114 (2d Cir. 2012)).

appellant_arguments: The Proxies contained material misstatements and omissions regarding the fairness of the merger, the financial projections (including MIIM revenue), and the process used to prepare those projections.
The misleading Proxies caused Monk and other minority shareholders to forfeit their appraisal rights, resulting in financial loss.
Monk is entitled to rely on the fraud-on-the-market presumption to establish reliance because the ADS traded on an efficient market.
The district court erred in finding that loss causation was not adequately pleaded, as Monk alleged he would have sought appraisal but for the misstatements.
The district court abused its discretion by denying leave to add Altimeo Asset Management as a named plaintiff without explanation.
appellee_arguments: The Proxies did not contain actionable misstatements or omissions; any alleged flaws in the projections or opinions were not material or were adequately disclosed.
Monk failed to adequately plead loss causation because he did not allege facts showing he was personally induced to forfeit his appraisal rights.
The fraud-on-the-market presumption does not apply in the context of a freeze-out merger where the market price is set by the merger price, not by market forces.
Monk did not plead scienter as to Shanda or the individual defendants, and any alleged motive to secure a low transaction price is not sufficient.
The district court properly denied leave to amend to add Altimeo, and any such amendment would be futile.

issue_1.reasoning: The district court dismissed for failure to plead loss causation, but Monk alleged that the misstatements and omissions in the Proxies caused him to forfeit his appraisal rights, resulting in a loss (as confirmed by the Cayman appraisal). Under Second Circuit precedent, loss causation can be adequately pleaded where a plaintiff alleges that but for the misstatements, he would have taken a different course of action (here, seeking appraisal). The complaint plausibly alleges a causal link between the alleged fraud and the economic loss.

issue_2.reasoning: The complaint alleges that the Proxies omitted or misrepresented material information about MIIM revenue and the fairness of the merger, and that the financial projections were misleading. Under Omnicare and Tongue, statements of opinion can be actionable if they omit material facts or are misleading in context. The allegations are sufficient at the pleading stage to survive a motion to dismiss.

issue_3.reasoning: The complaint alleges that insiders engineered a freeze-out merger at a price far below fair value, shortly after a successful product launch, and that they had a motive and opportunity to defraud minority shareholders. These allegations, taken as true, are sufficient to plead scienter under Tellabs and Kalnit at the motion to dismiss stage.

issue_4.reasoning: The fraud-on-the-market presumption can apply where the securities traded in an efficient market and the misstatements were public and material. The fact that the merger price was set by insiders does not preclude the presumption, especially where the market price may have been affected by the alleged misstatements. The district court previously found Monk could invoke the presumption, and there is no clear reason to disturb that finding.

issue_5.reasoning: Leave to amend should be freely given unless there is a valid reason to deny it. The district court denied leave to add Altimeo without explanation, and there is no indication of undue delay, prejudice, or futility. This is an abuse of discretion under Second Circuit precedent.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The district court's dismissal was based on pleading deficiencies that, under the applicable standards, are not supported by the record at this stage. The complaint plausibly alleges loss causation, actionable misstatements/omissions, scienter, and reliance, and the denial of leave to amend was not justified. The appellate court is likely to reverse on all issues and remand for further proceedings.

parties.appellant: 3M Company, defendant
parties.appellee: State of New Hampshire, plaintiff

stage1_summary.factual_background: In 2019, the State of New Hampshire filed two lawsuits in state court against 3M Company and several other chemical companies that produced synthetic chemical substances known as PFAS. The lawsuits allege that the defendants designed defective PFAS products, negligently marketed those products to users in New Hampshire, and concealed important information about PFAS toxicity from users and regulators. As a result, New Hampshire claims there has been widespread PFAS contamination of the state's natural resources, including water, soil, vegetation, and animal life. One lawsuit (the 'AFFF Suit') seeks damages only for PFAS from aqueous film-forming foam (AFFF) products and explicitly disclaims recovery for PFAS from non-AFFF products. The other lawsuit (the 'Non-AFFF Suit'), which is the subject of this appeal, seeks damages only for injuries attributable to PFAS-containing non-AFFF products and explicitly disclaims recovery for AFFF PFAS.

procedural_history.claims_brought: New Hampshire brought state law claims against 3M and other chemical companies for damages related to contamination of natural resources by non-AFFF PFAS products. The claims included allegations of defective design, negligence, and concealment of PFAS toxicity information. Trespass and public trust claims were dismissed by the state court.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court determined that the removal of the Non-AFFF Suit to federal court did not comply with the federal officer removal statute and, even if it did, that 3M's attempt to remove the case was untimely.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: 3M appeals the district court's order remanding the Non-AFFF Suit to state court, specifically challenging the district court's findings regarding the timeliness of removal and the applicability of the federal officer removal statute.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the appellate court has jurisdiction to hear the appeal after the case was remanded to state court and no stay was sought.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Appellate jurisdiction over remand orders under 28 U.S.C. § 1447(d), particularly for cases removed under the federal officer removal statute (28 U.S.C. § 1442(a)(1)).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the case was removable under the federal officer removal statute, 28 U.S.C. § 1442(a)(1), based on 3M's production of MilSpec AFFF for the federal government and alleged commingling of MilSpec AFFF PFAS and non-AFFF PFAS in New Hampshire's natural resources.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Federal officer removal statute (28 U.S.C. § 1442(a)(1)), including the 'nexus' requirement that the action is 'for or relating to' acts under color of federal office.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether 3M's attempt to remove the case was timely under 28 U.S.C. § 1446(b)(3), which requires removal within thirty days of receiving a pleading or other paper from which removability may be ascertained.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: 28 U.S.C. § 1446(b)(3): The thirty-day removal clock starts when the defendant receives a pleading, motion, order, or other paper from the plaintiff that provides sufficient information to easily determine that the matter is removable.

appellant_arguments: The existence of federal officer removal jurisdiction turns on whether the lawsuit is 'for or relating to' MilSpec AFFF, and the alleged commingling of MilSpec AFFF PFAS and non-AFFF PFAS in New Hampshire's natural resources satisfies the nexus requirement.
No plaintiff's paper prior to March 30, 2022, made clear that a court would need to determine the extent of commingling, so the removal was timely.
The complaint and other documents did not provide specific and unambiguous notice that the case was removable under the federal officer removal statute until shortly before removal.
appellee_arguments: The appellate court lacks jurisdiction because the case was formally remanded to state court and 3M did not seek a stay, leaving no procedural mechanism to retrieve the case.

3M's removal was untimely because New Hampshire's filings and other papers in the case provided sufficient notice of the alleged commingling and the basis for federal officer removal well before 3M filed for removal.

Documents from the record, including the complaint, a memorandum in support of an omnibus objection to motions to dismiss, and a transcript from the South Carolina MDL, made clear that the case involved alleged contamination by both MilSpec AFFF PFAS and non-AFFF PFAS.

issue_1.reasoning: Appellate jurisdiction over remand orders is strictly limited by 28 U.S.C. § 1447(d). While there is an exception for cases removed under the federal officer removal statute, the remand order here was already executed and no stay was sought. Precedent generally holds that once a remand order is executed and the case is returned to state court, the federal court loses jurisdiction to review the remand order. The appellee's argument is strong, and the appellate court is likely to find it lacks jurisdiction.

issue_2.reasoning: Even if the court were to reach the merits, the Non-AFFF Suit explicitly disclaims recovery for AFFF PFAS and seeks damages only for non-AFFF PFAS. The mere possibility of commingling does not create a sufficient 'nexus' under § 1442(a)(1) between the state law claims and 3M's actions under color of federal office. The district court's conclusion that the case is not removable under the federal officer removal statute is likely to be affirmed.

issue_3.reasoning: The record indicates that New Hampshire's filings and other papers provided sufficient notice of the alleged commingling and the potential for federal officer removal well before 3M's removal attempt. The thirty-day clock under § 1446(b)(3) likely began to run earlier than 3M claims, making the removal untimely. The district court's finding on untimeliness is likely to be affirmed.

stage2_decision.reasoning: All three issues favor affirmance. The appellate court is likely to find it lacks jurisdiction to review the remand order, and even if it did, the case was not removable under the federal officer removal statute and the removal was untimely. The district court's decision is well-supported by the record and applicable law.

parties.appellant: Y.G., K.O., Y.S., M.M., T.A., B.C., F.N., M.R., K.E., Y.S., N.A., T.H., J.P., V.W., N.L., N.G.B., M.Z., M.D., E.W., H.W. (each individually and on behalf of their respective children with disabilities); original role: plaintiffs in the district court
parties.appellee: New York City Department of Education; original role: defendant in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background: The plaintiffs are parents of children with disabilities who pursued administrative actions to enforce their children's rights under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA). After prevailing in these administrative proceedings, the plaintiffs, represented by the Cuddy Law Firm (CLF), sought to recover attorneys' fees and costs from the New York City Department of Education (NYCDOE) under the IDEA's fee-shifting provision. The parties were unable to reach an agreement regarding the amount of fees and costs, leading the plaintiffs to file lawsuits in federal court to recover these amounts.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs filed actions in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York seeking attorneys' fees and costs under the IDEA's fee-shifting provision (20 U.S.C. § 1415(i)(3)(B)(i)(I), (i)(3)(C)) after prevailing in administrative proceedings.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court calculated and awarded what it determined to be reasonable attorneys' fees and costs to the plaintiffs in each of the nineteen actions, using the lodestar method and considering the evidence and arguments presented by both parties.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appeal the district court's calculation of attorneys' fees and costs, challenging the amount awarded and the methodology used in determining the fee awards. In one case (N.G.B.), the NYCDOE also filed a cross-appeal regarding the fee award.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in its calculation of reasonable attorneys' fees and costs under the IDEA, including the hourly rates applied, the number of hours credited, and the application of discounts or deductions.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The IDEA allows courts to award reasonable attorneys' fees to prevailing parents, based on rates prevailing in the community for the kind and quality of services furnished. Courts use the lodestar method, multiplying the number of hours reasonably expended by a reasonable hourly rate, and may adjust for excessive, redundant, or unnecessary hours. The reasonable hourly rate is what a paying client would be willing to pay, considering all pertinent factors, including the Johnson factors.

appellant_arguments: The district court erred in its lodestar calculations by applying unreasonable hourly rates and/or by failing to credit all hours reasonably expended by counsel.

The district court improperly discounted or deducted hours and did not adequately consider the evidence or arguments presented by plaintiffs regarding prevailing rates and the complexity of the cases.
appellee_arguments: The district court properly exercised its discretion in determining reasonable hourly rates and hours expended, considering the evidence, prior awards, and relevant legal standards.
The district court appropriately applied discounts and deductions to exclude excessive, redundant, or unnecessary hours, and its methodology was consistent with the IDEA and Second Circuit precedent.

issue_1.reasoning: The calculation of reasonable attorneys' fees under the IDEA, including the determination of hourly rates, hours credited, and application of discounts, is reviewed for abuse of discretion. The district court used the lodestar method, considered the evidence and arguments from both sides, and applied relevant legal standards. Appellate courts are highly deferential to the district court's fee determinations unless there is a clear error in methodology or a failure to consider relevant factors. Here, the district court's approach appears consistent with precedent and within the range of reasonable outcomes, especially given the court's detailed consideration of the record.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The only issue on appeal is the calculation of attorneys' fees and costs, which is reviewed for abuse of discretion. The district court applied the correct legal standard, considered the evidence, and provided reasoned explanations for its determinations. There is no indication of a clear error or abuse of discretion. Therefore, the appellate court is likely to affirm the district court's fee awards.

parties.appellant: Grubhub Inc., Postmates Inc., and Uber Technologies, Inc. (Defendants in the district court, Appellants on appeal)
parties.appellee: Mariam Davitashvili and Adam Bensimon, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated; Philip Eliades, Jonathan Swaby, John Boisi, Nathan Obey (Plaintiffs in the district court, Appellees on appeal)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Defendants Grubhub, Postmates, and Uber Technologies operate online platforms (websites and mobile applications) that allow customers to order restaurant meals for pickup or delivery. Restaurants that use these platforms agree to 'no-price competition clauses' (NPCCs), which prohibit them from selling meals at lower prices through channels other than the defendants' platforms. Plaintiffs allege that these NPCCs have caused them to pay artificially high prices for restaurant meals. The putative class action is brought on behalf of three classes of restaurant customers: (1) those who purchased takeout or delivery goods directly from a restaurant subject to a defendant's NPCC; (2) those who purchased dine-in goods from a restaurant subject to a defendant's NPCC; and (3) those who purchased goods through a non-defendant's platform from a restaurant subject to a defendant's NPCC. Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief and damages based on both direct purchases from NPCC-bound restaurants through defendant platforms and indirect purchases from NPCC-bound restaurants through non-defendant platforms.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs filed a putative class action alleging violations of Section 1 of the Sherman Antitrust Act of 1890 and its state analogues, claiming that defendants' NPCCs resulted in artificially high restaurant meal prices.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court denied defendants' motion to compel arbitration. The court found that plaintiffs agreed to Uber's and Postmates's Terms of Use, but not Grubhub's. The court held that the enforceability of the arbitration clauses was a question for the court, not the arbitrator, and concluded that the arbitration clauses did not apply to plaintiffs' claims because the claims lacked any nexus to defendants' Terms of Use.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Defendants appeal the district court's denial of their motion to compel arbitration, specifically challenging the findings regarding (1) whether an agreement to arbitrate was made between defendants and plaintiffs; (2) whether the court or the arbitrator should decide arbitrability; and (3) whether the relevant arbitration clauses are enforceable and apply to plaintiffs' claims.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether an agreement to arbitrate was formed between each defendant and the plaintiffs.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Courts apply a standard similar to summary judgment, considering all relevant, admissible evidence and drawing all reasonable inferences in favor of the non-moving party. Ordinary state-law principles governing contract formation apply (here, New York law). The party seeking arbitration bears the initial burden of demonstrating that an agreement to arbitrate exists.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, under the circumstances, the question of arbitrability (i.e., whether the dispute is subject to arbitration) is for the court or the arbitrator to decide.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The issue of arbitrability is presumptively for the court to decide unless there is clear and unmistakable evidence that the parties agreed to delegate this question to the arbitrator. Incorporation of rules empowering the arbitrator to decide arbitrability can serve as such evidence.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the arbitration clauses in defendants' Terms of Use are enforceable and apply to plaintiffs' antitrust claims.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The scope of an arbitration agreement is determined by focusing on the factual allegations in the complaint rather than the legal causes of action asserted. The FAA's scope is limited to agreements to arbitrate controversies that 'arise out of' the parties' contractual relationship, requiring a causal or meaningful nexus between the claims and the contract containing the arbitration clause.

appellant_arguments: Plaintiffs assented to the Terms of Use, including arbitration clauses, of all defendants, including Grubhub.
The arbitration clauses are broad and encompass plaintiffs' antitrust claims because those claims relate to plaintiffs' access and use of the platforms.
For Uber and Postmates, the Terms of Use delegate questions of arbitrability to the arbitrator, and plaintiffs did not specifically challenge the delegation provision.

The district court erred in finding that the arbitration clauses did not apply to plaintiffs' claims and in deciding that the court, rather than the arbitrator, should determine arbitrability for Uber and Postmates.
appellee_arguments: Plaintiffs did not affirmatively assent to Grubhub's Terms of Use and thus are not bound by its arbitration clause.

Even if there was assent, the arbitration clauses do not apply to plaintiffs' antitrust claims because those claims do not arise out of or relate to the Terms of Use or plaintiffs' use of the platforms.
The enforceability of the arbitration clauses, including any delegation provisions, is a question for the court to decide.
The arbitration clauses are unconscionable or otherwise unenforceable as applied to the antitrust claims.

issue_1.reasoning: The district court found that plaintiffs did not assent to Grubhub's Terms of Use, and the record supports that plaintiffs did not affirmatively agree to Grubhub's terms. For Uber and Postmates, the court found assent, and that is not seriously disputed. The standard is de novo, and the evidence supports the district court's findings.

issue_2.reasoning: The question of who decides arbitrability is for the court unless there is clear and unmistakable evidence of delegation. While Uber and Postmates' Terms of Use may incorporate rules delegating arbitrability, the district court correctly found that the plaintiffs' challenge was to the scope of the arbitration clause, not just the delegation provision. Under recent Second Circuit and Supreme Court precedent, the court properly decided arbitrability.

issue_3.reasoning: The arbitration clauses only cover disputes 'arising out of or relating to' the Terms of Use or the use of the platforms. Plaintiffs' antitrust claims are based on the existence of NPCCs between defendants and restaurants, not on the plaintiffs' use of the platforms or the Terms of Use. There is insufficient nexus between the claims and the contracts to compel arbitration. The district court correctly found the arbitration clauses do not apply.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The district court's analysis is consistent with prevailing law on contract formation, delegation, and the scope of arbitration clauses. The factual record supports the findings on assent, and the legal analysis on arbitrability and scope is sound. The antitrust claims do not arise out of the Terms of Use, so the arbitration clauses do not apply. The court's decision is likely to be affirmed on all issues.

parties.appellant: John Conti, plaintiff (on behalf of himself and all others similarly situated)
parties.appellee: Citizens Bank, N.A., defendant (a national banking association chartered under the National Bank Act)

stage1_summary.factual_background: In July 2011, John Conti financed the purchase of a residential property in Rhode Island with a mortgage loan from Citizens Bank. The mortgage agreement required Conti to make advance payments of municipal property taxes and homeowner's insurance into an escrow account maintained by Citizens. Under the terms of the mortgage agreement, Citizens did not pay Conti interest or earnings on the escrow-account proceeds. Rhode Island General Laws section 19-9-2(a) requires all banks operating within the state to pay mortgage borrowers interest on the funds they deposit into mortgage-escrow accounts. Conti alleges that Citizens failed to pay interest on mortgage-escrow accounts as required by the Rhode Island statute.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Conti, on behalf of himself and a putative class of Citizens customers, filed suit in the United States District Court for the District of Rhode Island, asserting claims for breach of contract and unjust enrichment. He alleged that Citizens failed to pay interest on escrow accounts in violation of Rhode Island law. The action was brought on behalf of customers in Rhode Island and, alternatively, a narrower class of Rhode Island-based customers.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted Citizens' motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6), agreeing with Citizens that the National Bank Act preempts the application of the Rhode Island statute to national banks.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Conti appeals the district court's dismissal of his complaint, specifically challenging the finding that the National Bank Act preempts the Rhode Island interest-on-escrow statute.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court applied the correct legal standard for preemption under the National Bank Act, particularly in light of the Supreme Court's subsequent decision in Cantero v. Bank of America, N.A.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under 12 U.S.C. § 25b(b)(1), state consumer financial laws are preempted only if they discriminate against national banks or prevent or significantly interfere with the exercise of national bank powers, in accordance with the standard set forth in Barnett Bank of Marion County, N.A. v. Nelson and clarified in Cantero v. Bank of America, N.A. Courts must conduct a practical assessment of the nature and degree of interference and perform a comparative analysis with relevant Supreme Court precedents.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether, applying the Cantero standard, the Rhode Island statute requiring payment of interest on mortgage-escrow accounts is preempted by the National Bank Act as a matter of law.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The Cantero standard requires a nuanced comparative analysis of Supreme Court precedents to determine if the state law's interference with national bank powers is significant enough to warrant preemption. The burden of proving preemption lies with the party asserting it.

appellant_arguments: The district court failed to apply the proper test for preemption as outlined in Cantero v. Bank of America, N.A.
Applying the Cantero standard, Citizens has not shown that the Rhode Island statute significantly interferes with federal-banking power such that it should be preempted under the National Bank Act.
appellee_arguments: Even if the district court did not apply the Cantero standard, the dismissal should be affirmed because the Rhode Island statute is preempted under Cantero.

The Rhode Island statute significantly interferes with Citizens' express and incidental federal-banking powers by dictating terms of escrow accounts, impairing flexibility and efficiency, and subjecting national banks to a patchwork of varying state regulations.

issue_1.reasoning: The district court dismissed the complaint before the Supreme Court's decision in Cantero v. Bank of America, N.A., which clarified the preemption standard under the National Bank Act. The district court did not conduct the nuanced, comparative analysis required by Cantero, instead applying a broader preemption approach. Appellate courts reviewing dismissals for failure to state a claim and questions of law do so de novo, and here, the legal standard for preemption has changed. Therefore, the district court's application of the preemption standard was incorrect.

issue_2.reasoning: Applying the Cantero standard, the Supreme Court emphasized that state laws like interest-on-escrow statutes are not automatically preempted and require a fact-specific, comparative analysis. The burden is on the bank to show significant interference. The Rhode Island statute is a general consumer protection law, and Cantero suggests that such laws are not preempted absent a clear, significant interference with national bank powers. At the motion to dismiss stage, Citizens has not met its burden to show preemption as a matter of law. Therefore, the complaint should not have been dismissed on preemption grounds.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Both issues turn on the Supreme Court's recent clarification in Cantero, which requires a more searching, comparative analysis than the district court performed. The district court's legal error in applying the preemption standard and the insufficient showing of significant interference at the pleading stage mean that dismissal was premature. The appellate court is likely to reverse and remand for further proceedings under the correct standard.

parties.appellant: John Doe #1, John Doe #2, John Doe #3, John Doe #4, John Doe #5, John Doe #6, John Doe #7 (plaintiffs, victims of a 2016 Taliban attack, judgment creditors)
parties.appellee: Deposit Guarantee Fund (DGF) (intervenor-defendant, Ukrainian governmental entity that nationalized Prominvestbank)

stage1_summary.factual_background: The plaintiffs, United States citizens, were victims of a 2016 Taliban attack in Afghanistan. In November 2020, they obtained a default judgment in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Texas against the Taliban, Al-Qaeda, and the Haqqani Network for their alleged involvement in the attack. The plaintiffs sought to enforce this judgment by attaching funds in a New York bank account held in the name of Prominvestbank (PIB), which they alleged was an agency or instrumentality of the Taliban. Plaintiffs claimed that Russia used Vnesheconombank (VEB), a Russian state-owned bank and parent of PIB, to help the Taliban finance terrorist activities. The funds in question were held at the Bank of New York Mellon and had been blocked by the U.S. Treasury Department under Executive Orders 13662 and 14024 due to sanctions related to Russian activities.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs filed an action in September 2022 in the Northern District of New York, seeking to attach and execute on PIB's blocked assets under Section 201(a) of the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act of 2002 (TRIA) to satisfy their judgment against the Taliban and related entities.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court initially granted a writ of execution, attaching the funds in the PIB account. Subsequently, the Deposit Guarantee Fund (DGF), a Ukrainian governmental entity, intervened and moved to vacate the writ, arguing that Ukraine had nationalized PIB in May and September 2022, and thus VEB no longer had an ownership interest in PIB at the time the writ was sought. The district court granted DGF's motion to intervene and vacated the writ of execution based on the nationalization of PIB by Ukraine.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appealed the district court's order vacating the writ of execution, challenging the finding that Ukraine's nationalization of PIB precluded attachment of the assets. During the appeal, the U.S. Treasury Department removed PIB from the list of blocked entities, and the parties disputed the effect of this development on the plaintiffs' ability to execute their judgment.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in vacating the writ of execution on the grounds that Ukraine's nationalization of PIB meant the assets were no longer subject to attachment under TRIA.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: TRIA Section 201(a) allows execution against 'blocked assets' of a terrorist party or its agency/instrumentality. The definition of 'blocked asset' is any asset seized or frozen by the United States under specified authorities, including the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the subsequent removal of PIB from the list of blocked entities by the U.S. Treasury Department affects the plaintiffs' ability to execute their judgment against PIB's assets under TRIA.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: TRIA Section 201(a) requires that assets be 'blocked' at the time of execution. The effect of unblocking or delisting by the Treasury Department is governed by the statutory definition of 'blocked asset' and relevant regulations (e.g., 31 C.F.R. § 587.402).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the REPO Act or other recent legal developments impact the plaintiffs' ability to execute on the assets in question.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The REPO Act restricts the release or mobilization of certain Russian sovereign assets that are blocked or immobilized, subject to exceptions and presidential certification.

appellant_arguments: Ukraine's nationalization of PIB should not preclude attachment of the assets, as the relevant time for determining agency or instrumentality status is when the writ was sought.

The delisting and unblocking of PIB's assets by the Treasury Department does not defeat their pending TRIA execution, as once a TRIA writ attaches to blocked assets, subsequent executive action cannot defeat the execution.
The invocation of standard judicial processes and service of notice of the writ should preserve their rights to the assets, regardless of subsequent unblocking.
31 C.F.R. § 587.402 supports the position that subsequent amendments or revocations do not affect acts done or proceedings commenced prior to such changes.
appellee_arguments: Ukraine's nationalization of PIB prior to the plaintiffs' application for the writ means that PIB was no longer an agency or instrumentality of the Taliban, and thus the assets are not subject to attachment under TRIA.
The removal of PIB from the list of blocked entities by the Treasury Department means the assets are no longer 'blocked assets' under TRIA, and thus cannot be used to satisfy the judgment.
The REPO Act and subsequent unblocking orders by the Treasury Department specifically provide that the unblocking applies to assets at issue in pending TRIA proceedings, precluding execution.
The relevant regulations and statutory language do not guarantee that blocked assets will remain available for execution if the Executive Branch unblocks them.

issue_1.reasoning: The district court's decision to vacate the writ of execution turned on the legal question of whether PIB was an agency or instrumentality of the Taliban at the relevant time. The record shows that Ukraine nationalized PIB before the writ was sought, severing any connection between PIB and the Taliban or its affiliates. Under TRIA, only assets of a terrorist party or its agency/instrumentality are subject to execution. The plaintiffs' argument that the relevant time is when the writ was sought does not help them, as by that time, PIB was no longer an agency/instrumentality of the Taliban. Thus, the district court correctly vacated the writ.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether assets are 'blocked' under TRIA is a legal question. TRIA requires that assets be blocked at the time of execution. The Treasury Department's removal of PIB from the list of blocked entities means the assets are no longer 'blocked assets' under TRIA. The relevant regulation (31 C.F.R. § 587.402) does not guarantee that assets remain blocked for execution if the Executive unblocks them before execution is complete. Courts have generally held that unblocking precludes execution, even if judicial process was initiated before unblocking. Thus, the district court's decision is supported by the current status of the assets.
