issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Every contract in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, which prohibits either party from doing anything that would destroy or injure the right of the other party to receive the fruits of the contract. The covenant cannot create rights and duties not otherwise provided for in the contract.

appellant_arguments: Axis contends that the district court improperly focused on the legal status of the parties' relationship rather than the factual circumstances, and that vicarious or derivative liability can arise based on the facts, not just the legal characterization of the relationship.

Axis argues that Barracuda waived the OEM's condition precedent by failing to exercise its contractual right to audit Fusion's customer contracts and that Barracuda's inaction over the years led Fusion to believe it was in compliance.
Axis asserts that Barracuda is estopped from relying on the condition precedent because its silence and inaction induced Fusion's reliance.

Axis claims that Barracuda breached the covenant of good faith and fair dealing by depriving Fusion of the benefit of its contractual bargain, including being slow to provide information about the data breach, providing information in an unusable format, interfering with investigations, and misrepresenting details of the breach.
appellee_arguments: Barracuda argues that equitable indemnification is not available because there was no relationship between Zoll and Barracuda that could support derivative or vicarious liability under Massachusetts law.

Barracuda contends that Fusion failed to fulfill a condition precedent in the OEM by not including the required limitation of liability or indemnification language in its customer contracts, and that Barracuda did not waive this condition, as its inaction or silence does not constitute waiver.
Barracuda maintains that it is not estopped from relying on the condition precedent because it had no duty to act or to audit Fusion's customer contracts.

Barracuda argues that the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing cannot be used to create contractual rights that do not exist, and that Axis failed to identify any contractual right to which Fusion was entitled in the event of a data breach.

issue_1.reasoning: The standard for equitable indemnification under Massachusetts law is strict: it requires a legally recognized relationship (e.g., employer-employee, principal-agent) that gives rise to vicarious or derivative liability. Here, Zoll and Barracuda were not in such a relationship; their connection was indirect, through Fusion. The district court correctly found that the facts do not support the type of relationship required for equitable indemnification. Axis's argument that factual circumstances alone can create such liability is not supported by Massachusetts precedent.

issue_2.reasoning: The OEM agreement unambiguously required Fusion to include certain provisions in its customer contracts as a condition precedent to Barracuda's obligations. The record shows Fusion did not do so. Waiver requires clear, unequivocal conduct, and mere inaction or failure to audit is generally insufficient under Massachusetts law. The evidence does not show Barracuda intentionally relinquished its right to enforce the condition. Similarly, estoppel requires a representation and reasonable reliance, which is not present here. The district court properly granted summary judgment.

issue_3.reasoning: The implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing cannot create new contractual rights. Axis failed to identify a specific contractual right Fusion was deprived of; the contract did not guarantee indemnification or specific data breach remedies absent satisfaction of the condition precedent. Barracuda's alleged conduct does not amount to a breach of the covenant in the absence of a contractual right to the claimed benefit.

stage2_decision.reasoning: All three issues turn on well-settled principles of Massachusetts law and contract interpretation. The district court's summary judgment rulings are supported by the undisputed facts and the applicable legal standards. The relationships and conduct at issue do not meet the requirements for equitable indemnification, waiver, estoppel, or breach of the implied covenant. The appellate court is likely to affirm in full.

parties.appellant: Zoe Hollis, plaintiff (individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated)
parties.appellee: R&R Restaurants, Inc. (doing business as Sassy's), Stacy Mayhood, Ian Hannigan, Frank Faillace, defendants (owners and managers of Sassy's and Dante's)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Zoe Hollis worked as a dancer at Sassy’s, a Portland strip club, from June 2017 until March 2019, typically three to five times a week, under a contract that classified them as an independent contractor. Sassy’s exercised significant control over the work environment, including scheduling, customer entry, pricing, music selection, and dancer conduct. Dancers were required to pay 'house fees' per shift and tip other staff, but did not have management responsibilities or pay for club facilities. Hollis also performed at Dante’s, another club managed by Frank Faillace, on two occasions and was scheduled for a third performance. After Hollis filed a lawsuit against Sassy’s for wage and hour violations, Faillace canceled Hollis’s upcoming performance at Dante’s, citing the lawsuit as the reason and expressing concern about legal liability for Dante’s. Hollis then amended their complaint to allege that this cancellation constituted unlawful retaliation.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Hollis filed a collective action under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) against R&R Restaurants, Stacy Mayhood, and Ian Hannigan, alleging misclassification of dancers as independent contractors, failure to pay minimum wage and overtime, illegal kickbacks in the form of house fees, and unlawful retention of tips. After Faillace canceled Hollis’s performance at Dante’s, Hollis amended the complaint to add Faillace as a defendant and to assert a retaliation claim under the FLSA and Oregon state law.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted summary judgment to the defendants. The court found that Hollis’s wage-related claims were barred by the statute of limitations. The court also concluded that Hollis’s FLSA retaliation claim failed as a matter of law because Hollis was not an employee of Dante’s or Faillace at the time of the alleged retaliation. The state-law retaliation claims were dismissed without prejudice.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Hollis appeals the district court’s grant of summary judgment on the FLSA retaliation claim, specifically challenging the requirement that Hollis must have been employed by Dante’s at the time of the alleged retaliation.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the FLSA retaliation provision requires the plaintiff to have been employed by the retaliator (Dante’s/Faillace) at the time of the alleged retaliation.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Interpretation of the FLSA’s anti-retaliation provision (29 U.S.C. § 215(a)(3)), the definition of 'employer' (29 U.S.C. § 203(d)), and relevant precedent (e.g., Arias v. Raimondo) regarding who may be liable for retaliation and the scope of protected relationships.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Hollis can establish an employer-employee relationship with Sassy’s for purposes of the FLSA retaliation claim, even though the underlying wage and hour claims are time-barred.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Application of the 'economic realities' test to determine employee status under the FLSA (see Real v. Driscoll Strawberry Assocs., Inc.; Torres-Lopez v. May), and whether the statute of limitations on wage claims precludes establishing employee status for a retaliation claim.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Faillace’s cancellation of Hollis’s scheduled performance and barring of future work at Dante’s constitutes actionable retaliation under the FLSA.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The FLSA’s anti-retaliation provision (29 U.S.C. § 215(a)(3)), which prohibits discrimination against an employee for filing a complaint, and the standard for what constitutes an adverse action (including the 'reasonable worker' standard from Burlington N. & Santa Fe Ry. Co. v. White).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Faillace’s stated business justification for canceling Hollis’s performance (to protect Dante’s from legal liability) precludes a finding of retaliation as a matter of law.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Whether a legitimate, nonretaliatory business reason can defeat a retaliation claim under the FLSA, and the burden-shifting framework for evaluating such defenses.

appellant_arguments: The FLSA’s anti-retaliation provision does not require the plaintiff to be employed by the retaliator at the time of the alleged retaliation; it is sufficient that the retaliation was in response to protected activity related to the plaintiff’s employment at Sassy’s.
Hollis was an employee of Sassy’s under the economic realities test, regardless of the time-barred status of the underlying wage claims.
Faillace’s cancellation of the performance and barring of future work at Dante’s was motivated by Hollis’s protected activity (the lawsuit) and constitutes actionable retaliation under the FLSA.
A business justification based on avoiding legal liability does not excuse or legitimize retaliatory conduct under the FLSA.
appellee_arguments: The FLSA only provides a private right of action for retaliation committed by a current employer; Hollis was not employed by Dante’s or Faillace at the time of the alleged retaliation.
Hollis cannot establish an employer-employee relationship with Sassy’s for purposes of the retaliation claim because the underlying misclassification and wage claims are time-barred.
Faillace’s actions were a legitimate business decision to protect Dante’s from potential legal exposure, not retaliation.
Hollis was allowed to continue providing trainings for Dante’s and other clubs, indicating the decision was not retaliatory but based on business necessity.

issue_1.reasoning: This is a question of statutory interpretation. The FLSA’s anti-retaliation provision has been interpreted broadly by courts, including the Ninth Circuit in Arias v. Raimondo, to cover retaliation by non-employers if the retaliation is in response to protected activity. The district court erred in requiring a current employment relationship with the retaliator. The appellate court is likely to reverse on this point.

issue_2.reasoning: While the economic realities test may establish Hollis as an employee of Sassy’s, the underlying wage claims are time-barred. However, for the retaliation claim, employee status is still relevant. The appellate court may find that the time-barred status of the wage claims does not preclude Hollis from being considered an employee for the purpose of the retaliation claim, but since the district court dismissed on other grounds, this issue may be rendered moot or affirmed on alternative grounds.

issue_3.reasoning: Whether the cancellation of a scheduled performance and barring of future work constitutes actionable retaliation is a legal question. Under Burlington Northern, such actions would dissuade a reasonable worker from engaging in protected activity and thus qualify as adverse actions. The appellate court is likely to reverse the district court’s conclusion that these actions are not actionable retaliation.

issue_4.reasoning: The existence of a purported business justification does not preclude a retaliation claim as a matter of law; it is a factual question for the jury under the burden-shifting framework. The district court erred in granting summary judgment on this basis.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The district court’s summary judgment was based on a narrow reading of the FLSA’s anti-retaliation provision and an improper requirement of a current employment relationship with the retaliator. Precedent (notably Arias v. Raimondo) supports a broader interpretation. The adverse action and business justification issues are not suitable for summary judgment. The only possible affirmance is on the time-barred wage claims, but that does not defeat the retaliation claim. Thus, the appellate court is likely to reverse and remand for further proceedings on the retaliation claim.

parties.appellant: Erik Blecher, James Bruno, Robert Burns, Emmett Caldwell, Louis Castiglione, Kevin Cavanaugh, Brian Compasso, Wayne Compasso, Vincent Dillard, John Gillen, Stephen Hurn, Joseph Jockel, Marianne Agnello, Dianne Mondello, Vernon Allen Jones, Michael Leonard, John O’Connor, Thomas O’Connor, Daniel Rice, Joseph Russo, Tom Sparks, Peter Senatore, Matthew Sexton, Lawrence Smith, Jordan Taylor, Desiree Callender, Jacqueline Regan, Michael Gill, Neil M. Curtis, and Robert Lisiecki, on behalf of themselves and all persons similarly situated (plaintiffs in the district court)
parties.appellee: The Holy See, aka the Apostolic See (defendant in the district court)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Plaintiffs are thirty survivors of childhood sexual abuse who allege they were abused in the 1960s through 1990s by named clerics of various New York Catholic dioceses. They seek damages for negligence from the Holy See under a vicarious liability theory. Plaintiffs allege that the Holy See promulgated a mandatory policy of secrecy, known as 'Crimen Sollicitationis,' which governed how its dioceses and bishops handled reports of sexual abuse by clerics. This policy, initially promulgated in 1922 and reiterated in later documents, allegedly required strict secrecy regarding abuse allegations, prohibited disclosure to law enforcement, and instructed victims and families not to report abuse. Plaintiffs claim that, in adhering to this policy, bishops in the Archdiocese of New York, the Diocese of Brooklyn, the Diocese of Rockville Centre, the Diocese of Albany, the Diocese of Syracuse, and the Diocese of Ogdensburg failed to warn children and parents of the dangers posed by accused clerics and failed to report suspected abuse to law enforcement. Plaintiffs allege that this emboldened abusers and exposed children to foreseeable risk of harm. The Holy See is alleged to direct the activities of the Catholic Church worldwide, with bishops and archbishops conducting local activities under its direction and control. Plaintiffs assert that bishops in the U.S. are employees of the Holy See.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs filed a putative class action against the Holy See in May 2020, asserting negligence claims under a vicarious liability theory for physical and psychological injuries resulting from childhood sexual abuse by clerics. The claims are based on the alleged failure of bishops to warn and report, in accordance with the Holy See's secrecy policy.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted the Holy See’s motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act (FSIA). The court found that the New York dioceses were separate juridical entities from the Holy See and that the Holy See could not be held vicariously liable for the dioceses’ conduct. However, the court determined that the bishops were employees of the Holy See and that the Holy See could, in principle, be vicariously liable for their conduct. The court found that the FSIA’s tortious activity exception could apply to the bishops’ conduct, but ultimately concluded that the discretionary function exclusion from the FSIA’s tortious activity exception barred plaintiffs’ claims.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appeal the district court’s dismissal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, specifically challenging the application of the discretionary function exclusion from the FSIA’s tortious activity exception to their claims based on the bishops’ conduct in implementing the Holy See’s secrecy policy.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the discretionary function exclusion from the tortious activity exception of the FSIA precludes federal courts from exercising jurisdiction over claims against the Holy See concerning child sexual abuse perpetrated by clerics in the United States, where the alleged tortious conduct was the bishops’ adherence to the Holy See’s mandatory secrecy policy.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The Berkovitz/Gaubert test, derived from Supreme Court precedent interpreting the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) and applied to the FSIA, requires that (1) the challenged act or omission is discretionary, involving an element of judgment or choice, and (2) the judgment or choice is grounded in considerations of public policy or is susceptible to policy analysis.

appellant_arguments: The district court improperly applied the discretionary function exclusion because the complaint plausibly alleges tortious conduct that involved no discretion by the bishops; the bishops’ conduct was compelled by the Holy See’s mandatory secrecy policy.
The existence of a mandatory policy forecloses application of the discretionary function exclusion under the first prong of the Berkovitz/Gaubert test.
The Holy See’s policy of secrecy was not susceptible to policy analysis and there can be no plausible policy justification for maintaining secrecy about illegal conduct such as child sexual abuse.
appellee_arguments: The bishops’ challenged conduct involved discretionary acts, particularly in the assignment of clergy to parishes, which is a quintessentially discretionary function.

The discretionary function exclusion applies to acts taken in compliance with a mandatory policy, as such acts are in furtherance of the policy considerations that led to the promulgation of the policy.

The bishops’ decisions regarding warning or reporting were susceptible to policy analysis, involving considerations such as parishioners’ well-being, church reputation, staffing, and other resource allocation concerns.

issue_1.reasoning: The standard of review for subject matter jurisdiction and the application of the FSIA’s discretionary function exclusion is de novo. Plaintiffs plausibly allege that the bishops’ conduct was not discretionary because it was compelled by a mandatory secrecy policy promulgated by the Holy See. Under the first prong of the Berkovitz/Gaubert test, if a policy is mandatory and leaves no room for discretion, the discretionary function exclusion does not apply. The complaint alleges that the bishops had no choice but to follow the secrecy policy, which, if true, would mean their conduct was not discretionary. Courts have held that mandatory directives foreclose the application of the discretionary function exclusion. The district court erred in finding otherwise at the motion to dismiss stage, where the allegations must be taken as true.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The key issue is whether the bishops’ conduct was discretionary or compelled by a mandatory policy. The complaint plausibly alleges a lack of discretion, which, under the Berkovitz/Gaubert test, means the discretionary function exclusion does not apply. At the pleading stage, the court must accept these allegations as true. Therefore, the district court’s dismissal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction was premature and should be reversed to allow further proceedings.

parties.appellant: Local 14A, Rochester Regional Joint Board, Xerographic Division Workers United (Union), respondent in the district court
parties.appellee: Xerox Corporation, petitioner in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background: Xerox Corporation and Local 14A, Rochester Regional Joint Board, Xerographic Division Workers United (the Union) had a longstanding relationship governed by successive collective bargaining agreements (CBAs). The most recent CBA between the parties was effective from June 11, 2018, through November 30, 2021, after an extension. This CBA covered various employment terms, including retiree benefits, and incorporated by reference detailed plan documents for retiree health and life insurance benefits. After the CBA expired and no successor agreement was reached, Xerox announced modifications to health benefits for employees who retired before the CBA's expiration. In January 2022, Xerox implemented these changes, which, according to the Union, resulted in the termination of retiree benefits for thousands of retirees and their families. The Union filed a grievance and demanded arbitration, arguing that the retiree benefits had vested under the CBA and could not be unilaterally terminated by Xerox. Xerox denied the grievance and refused to arbitrate, asserting that the CBA had expired and that no benefits had vested beyond its expiration.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Xerox filed a petition in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York under Section 301 of the Labor Management Relations Act (LMRA), seeking to stay and enjoin arbitration and for declaratory relief. Xerox argued that the Union could not enforce the expired CBA's arbitration provision because the agreement had expired and no retiree benefits had vested. The Union filed an answer, moved to dismiss Xerox's petition, and cross-moved to compel arbitration and for injunctive relief pending arbitration, arguing that the CBA and incorporated plan documents contained language capable of being interpreted as vesting retiree benefits.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted Xerox's petition, staying and enjoining arbitration and granting declaratory relief. The court concluded that the Union's grievance was not arbitrable under the expired CBA, reasoning that the Union had not identified language in the agreement that could be understood as promising vested benefits beyond the agreement's expiration, and that a reservation-of-rights clause in the plan documents barred an interpretation that benefits had vested.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The Union appealed the district court's decision, challenging the finding that the grievance was not arbitrable and that retiree benefits had not vested under the CBA.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in concluding that the Union's grievance regarding retiree benefits was not arbitrable under the expired CBA.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A post-expiration grievance is arbitrable if it involves facts or occurrences that arose before expiration, if an action taken after expiration infringes a right that accrued or vested under the agreement, or if the disputed contractual right survives expiration under normal principles of contract interpretation (Litton Fin. Printing Div., Litton Bus. Sys., Inc. v. NLRB, 501 U.S. 190, 205–06 (1991)). In the Second Circuit, a party need only point to written language capable of reasonably being interpreted as creating a promise to vest benefits to reach a trier of fact (Am. Fed’n of Grain Millers v. Int’l Multifoods Corp., 116 F.3d 976, 980 (2d Cir. 1997)).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in finding that the CBA and incorporated plan documents did not contain language capable of being interpreted as vesting retiree benefits beyond the CBA's expiration.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Ordinary principles of contract law apply to the interpretation of CBAs (M & G Polymers USA, LLC v. Tackett, 574 U.S. 427, 435 (2015)). A contract is ambiguous if, after applying established rules of interpretation, it remains reasonably susceptible to at least two reasonable but conflicting meanings (CNH Indus. N.V. v. Reese, 583 U.S. 133, 139 (2018)).

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the reservation-of-rights clause in the plan documents precludes any interpretation that retiree benefits had vested under the CBA.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A reservation-of-rights clause in plan documents may preclude a finding of vested benefits if it is unambiguous and clearly incorporated, but if the CBA or plan documents contain language capable of being interpreted as promising vested benefits, the effect of a reservation-of-rights clause may be ambiguous and require consideration of extrinsic evidence (see Abbruscato v. Empire Blue Cross & Blue Shield, 274 F.3d 90 (2d Cir. 2001)).

appellant_arguments: The Union identified language in the CBA and incorporated plan documents that could reasonably be interpreted as guaranteeing retiree benefits beyond the contract’s expiration or as constituting deferred compensation.

The survivor benefits clause and other provisions in the plan documents state that participation continues until the retiree’s or surviving spouse’s death, which could be interpreted as vesting benefits.
The reservation-of-rights clause in the plan documents does not conclusively bar an interpretation that benefits had vested, especially when read in conjunction with the CBA.
The district court failed to consider that extrinsic evidence may be necessary to discern the parties’ intent regarding vesting.
appellee_arguments: The CBA and incorporated plan documents lack clear and unambiguous language sufficient to vest retiree benefits for life or beyond the CBA’s expiration.

The reservation-of-rights clause in the plan documents expressly permits Xerox to amend, suspend, or terminate the plans at any time and for any reason, precluding any interpretation that benefits had vested.
The grievance is not arbitrable because the CBA’s arbitration provision expired with the CBA and does not apply to retirees.
Any references to benefits continuing until death or other events are not sufficient to establish vesting, especially in light of the reservation-of-rights clause.

issue_1.reasoning: Whether a grievance is arbitrable is a question of law reviewed de novo. Under Litton and Second Circuit precedent, a post-expiration grievance is arbitrable if the underlying right arguably survived expiration. The Union pointed to language in the CBA and plan documents that could reasonably be interpreted as vesting retiree benefits. The Second Circuit has held that if there is any language reasonably susceptible to such an interpretation, the issue of vesting should go to arbitration. The district court erred by resolving the vesting question itself rather than sending the arbitrability question to arbitration.

issue_2.reasoning: Interpretation of contract language is reviewed de novo. The Union identified language (e.g., survivor benefits, continuation until death) that could be reasonably interpreted as vesting benefits. Under Tackett and CNH, if the contract is ambiguous or susceptible to more than one reasonable interpretation, the issue should not be resolved on the pleadings. The district court erred by finding no ambiguity and by not allowing the issue to proceed to arbitration or trial.

issue_3.reasoning: The effect of a reservation-of-rights clause is a legal question reviewed de novo. The Second Circuit has held that such a clause does not automatically preclude vesting if other language in the CBA or plan documents could be interpreted as promising vested benefits. Here, the Union pointed to such language, making the effect of the reservation-of-rights clause at least ambiguous. The district court erred in holding that the clause conclusively barred vesting as a matter of law.

stage2_decision.reasoning: All three issues turn on whether the CBA and plan documents contain language reasonably susceptible to an interpretation that retiree benefits vested. Second Circuit precedent is clear that if such language exists, the dispute is arbitrable and the question of vesting should not be resolved on the pleadings. The district court erred by deciding the merits of vesting and arbitrability rather than compelling arbitration. The appellate court is likely to reverse and remand with instructions to compel arbitration.

parties.appellant: Kevin Christie and Bor Yang, defendants (members of the Vermont Human Rights Commission), appellants/cross-appellees
parties.appellee: Andrew Leise, plaintiff, appellee/cross-appellant; Vermont Human Rights Commission, defendant-appellee

stage1_summary.factual_background: The case arises from a landlord-tenant dispute between Dr. Lydia Clemmons and a tenant renting an outbuilding on her Vermont farm. In 2017, Dr. Clemmons contacted the Vermont State Police (VSP) multiple times, requesting intervention in disputes with her tenant. VSP troopers, including Andrew Leise, responded to these calls. Dr. Clemmons believed the troopers disregarded her complaints and subsequently filed a discrimination complaint with the Vermont Human Rights Commission (VHRC), alleging the VSP discriminated against her based on sex and race. The VHRC investigated and produced an Investigative Report recommending a finding of discrimination by the VSP, explicitly naming and criticizing Leise. On March 25, 2021, the VHRC commissioners found reasonable grounds to believe discrimination had occurred. On June 10, 2021, the VHRC released the Investigative Report to Seven Days, a local newspaper operated by Da Capo Publishing, Inc., which published an article on June 23, 2021, making the report public. Leise alleges that Christie and Yang participated in providing the report to the newspaper, that the report was based on intentionally false and misleading facts, and that its release violated Vermont law requiring confidentiality. He claims the release damaged his reputation, forced his resignation from the VSP, and harmed his future employment prospects. Leise further alleges that Christie and Yang authored the report and released it to promote VHRC leadership and shape public opinion against the VSP and its troopers.

procedural_history.claims_brought: On January 18, 2022, Leise filed suit against the VHRC, Christie, and Yang (in both official and individual capacities), asserting six claims: (1) liberty-interest procedural due process under 42 U.S.C. § 1983; (2) property-interest procedural due process under § 1983; (3) substantive due process for arbitrary, oppressive, and conscience-shocking government action under § 1983; (4) invasion of privacy under Vermont law; (5) defamation under Vermont law; and (6) tortious interference with contract under Vermont law. The same claims were brought against Da Capo Publishing, Inc., which were dismissed by the district court (not at issue on appeal).
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion to dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6). It dismissed all claims against the VHRC, Christie, and Yang in their official capacities on sovereign immunity grounds, and dismissed the § 1983 and state law claims against Christie and Yang in their individual capacities on absolute immunity grounds to the extent they related to the VHRC's investigation, decision-making, and final determination. The court denied the motion to dismiss as to Leise's claims against Christie and Yang in their individual capacities under § 1983 (to the extent they related to the release of the Investigative Report) and the state law defamation and invasion of privacy claims. The court found Christie and Yang were not entitled to federal qualified immunity at the motion to dismiss stage for the § 1983 claims related to the release of the report, and could not determine entitlement to state qualified immunity for the state law claims. Upon reconsideration, the court dismissed Leise's procedural due process claims but allowed the substantive due process claim to proceed.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Christie and Yang appeal the denial of qualified immunity for the federal substantive due process claim and the state law defamation and invasion of privacy claims. Leise cross-appeals the dismissal of his claims against the VHRC and the official capacity claims against Christie and Yang, challenging the finding that the VHRC is entitled to state sovereign immunity.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Christie and Yang are entitled to federal qualified immunity on Leise's substantive due process claim under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, based on the release of the Investigative Report.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Qualified immunity protects government officials from liability for civil damages insofar as their conduct does not violate clearly established statutory or constitutional rights of which a reasonable person would have known. The analysis considers whether the official violated a statutory or constitutional right and whether the right was clearly established at the time of the conduct.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether Christie and Yang are entitled to qualified immunity under Vermont law for Leise's state law claims of defamation and invasion of privacy.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Vermont law, state officials are entitled to qualified immunity if they were (1) acting during the course of their employment and within the scope of their authority; (2) acting in good faith; and (3) performing discretionary, as opposed to ministerial, acts.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the VHRC is entitled to state sovereign immunity as an arm of the State of Vermont, thereby barring Leise's claims against the VHRC and the official capacity claims against Christie and Yang.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: The determination of whether an entity is an 'arm of the state' considers: (1) the extent to which the state would be responsible for satisfying any judgment; (2) the degree of control exercised by the state over the entity; (3) how the entity is referred to in the documents that created it; and (4) whether the entity's function is traditionally one of local or state government.

appellant_arguments: Christie and Yang argue they are entitled to federal qualified immunity because releasing the Investigative Report did not violate clearly established law, as Vermont law is ambiguous regarding the confidentiality of such reports.
They contend they are entitled to qualified immunity under Vermont law for the state law claims, asserting their actions were within the scope of their employment, discretionary, and in good faith.
They argue the district court erred in denying their motion to dismiss and motion for reconsideration as to the federal substantive due process and state law claims.
appellee_arguments: Leise argues that Christie and Yang are not entitled to qualified immunity because the release of the Investigative Report was unlawful under Vermont law and violated his clearly established constitutional rights.
He contends that the Investigative Report was based on false and misleading information and its release was intentional and malicious, causing him reputational and professional harm.
On cross-appeal, Leise argues that the VHRC is not an arm of the State of Vermont and therefore not entitled to sovereign immunity, as it is an independent entity.

issue_1.reasoning: Qualified immunity is reviewed de novo. The key question is whether the release of the Investigative Report violated a clearly established substantive due process right. Courts are generally reluctant to recognize reputational harm from government speech as a substantive due process violation unless it is accompanied by a more tangible deprivation (the 'stigma-plus' doctrine). The law is not clearly established that releasing a critical report, even if damaging, violates substantive due process. Furthermore, the confidentiality of such reports under Vermont law is ambiguous, making it unlikely that a reasonable official would know their conduct was unlawful. Therefore, Christie and Yang are entitled to qualified immunity on the substantive due process claim.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether state qualified immunity applies is a legal question reviewed de novo. Vermont law provides qualified immunity to officials acting within the scope of their employment, in good faith, and performing discretionary acts. The release of the report appears to be a discretionary act within their official duties. There is no clear evidence at the pleading stage of bad faith or conduct outside the scope of employment. Thus, Christie and Yang are entitled to qualified immunity under Vermont law for the defamation and invasion of privacy claims.

issue_3.reasoning: Whether the VHRC is an arm of the state is a legal question reviewed de novo. The VHRC is created by state statute, its funding and judgments are the responsibility of the state, and it performs a core state function (enforcing anti-discrimination law). The district court correctly found that the VHRC is an arm of the state and entitled to sovereign immunity, barring claims against it and official capacity claims against its members.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The district court erred in denying qualified immunity to Christie and Yang on both the federal substantive due process claim and the state law claims, as the law was not clearly established and their actions were within the scope of their discretionary duties. The district court correctly found the VHRC is an arm of the state and entitled to sovereign immunity. Thus, the appellate court will reverse the denial of qualified immunity and affirm the sovereign immunity ruling, resulting in reversal of the district court's decision to allow the claims against Christie and Yang to proceed.

parties.appellant: Ernst Jacob GmbH & Co. KG and Shipowners Insurance & Guaranty Company, Ltd. (defendants, third-party plaintiffs, appellants)
parties.appellee: United States (plaintiff, appellee)

stage1_summary.factual_background: In April 2006, the T/V Margara, a 748-foot double-hulled oil tanker carrying over 300,000 barrels of oil, ran aground approximately three miles off the coast of Tallaboa, Puerto Rico. Ernst Jacob GmbH & Co. KG owned or operated the vessel, and Shipowners Insurance & Guaranty Company, Ltd. (SIGCo) acted as an insurer. The crew notified the U.S. Coast Guard after failing to free the vessel. Captain James Tunstall, the pre-designated Federal On-Scene Coordinator (FOSC), oversaw the response. The Coast Guard deployed booms to contain oil in case of a spill and oversaw the vessel's return to deeper waters. No oil was spilled, and the hull survey revealed only cosmetic damage. However, the response efforts to free the vessel and mitigate the risk of a spill resulted in the destruction or destabilization of nearly 7,000 square meters of coral reef. NOAA and the Puerto Rico Department of Natural and Environmental Resources (PRDNER) worked together to assess and restore the damaged natural resources, including coral, reef biota, and habitat. In 2015, they published a restoration plan and later presented claims for restoration costs to the vessel's representatives and insurers, which were denied or not answered. NOAA and PRDNER then sought and received compensation from the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund (the Fund) managed by the U.S. Coast Guard's National Pollution Funds Center (NPFC). The NPFC paid over $4.4 million for primary restoration and additional contingency funds. NOAA and PRDNER later finalized a natural resource damages assessment, estimating further restoration costs at nearly $29.4 million, and presented additional claims for compensatory restoration and assessment costs to SIGCo and Ernst Jacob.

procedural_history.claims_brought: The United States, on behalf of the NPFC (as subrogee) and NOAA, filed claims under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (OPA), 33 U.S.C. § 2702(a), seeking damages for injury to natural resources resulting from the T/V Margara grounding. The first claim sought recovery for damages compensated by the Fund; the second claim sought uncompensated damages, including restoration and assessment costs. PRDNER intervened with its own claims under OPA and Puerto Rico law (not at issue in this appeal). The defendants (Ernst Jacob and SIGCo) filed third-party complaints for subrogation or contribution against Margara Shipping Ltd. and Steamship Mutual Underwriting Association Ltd.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted the United States' motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of liability under OPA § 2702(a), finding that the only contested element was whether the vessel posed a 'substantial threat of a discharge of oil.' The court determined that the authority to make this determination was delegated to the Coast Guard FOSC, and reviewed the FOSC's decision under the Administrative Procedure Act's arbitrary and capricious standard, concluding that the FOSC's determination was not arbitrary or capricious. The court did not explicitly address whether the natural resources at issue were 'belonging to, managed by, controlled by, or appertaining to the United States.'
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The defendants appeal the grant of partial summary judgment as to liability under OPA § 2702(a), specifically challenging the district court's application of the arbitrary and capricious standard to the FOSC's 'substantial threat' determination and the failure to address whether the United States had the requisite relationship to the natural resources to bring the claims.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in granting summary judgment on liability by applying the arbitrary and capricious standard to the FOSC's determination that the grounding posed a 'substantial threat of a discharge of oil,' rather than requiring the United States to prove this element by a preponderance of the evidence.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Ordinarily, civil claims require proof by a preponderance of the evidence unless a statute dictates otherwise. The Administrative Procedure Act (APA) arbitrary and capricious standard applies to judicial review of certain agency actions, but only if Congress has delegated the relevant determination to the agency for purposes of the claim at issue.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the United States has statutory standing to bring claims for damages to the natural resources at issue, i.e., whether the coral reef and related resources are 'belonging to, managed by, controlled by, or appertaining to the United States' as required by OPA § 2706(a)(1).
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under OPA § 2706(a)(1), the United States may recover for natural resource damages only if the resources are 'belonging to, managed by, controlled by, or appertaining to the United States.' The burden is on the United States to establish this relationship as an element of its claim.

appellant_arguments: The district court erred by applying the arbitrary and capricious standard to the FOSC's 'substantial threat' determination; the proper standard is preponderance of the evidence, as the 'substantial threat' is an element of liability under OPA § 2702(a).

The United States lacks statutory standing to bring claims for damages to these natural resources because they are not 'belonging to, managed by, controlled by, or appertaining to the United States,' but rather are under the exclusive control of Puerto Rico pursuant to the Federal Relations Act.
Even if the FOSC's determination is relevant, there are genuine disputes of material fact as to whether a 'substantial threat' existed, and discovery is necessary.
If the arbitrary and capricious standard were to apply, the administrative record is incomplete and does not support summary judgment.
appellee_arguments: Congress delegated the authority to determine whether an incident posed a 'substantial threat of a discharge of oil' to the Coast Guard FOSC under 33 U.S.C. § 1321(c) and related regulations; thus, the FOSC's determination is subject to deferential review under the APA.
The United States manages and controls the natural resources at issue through various federal statutes and as a co-trustee with Puerto Rico, satisfying the requirements of OPA § 2706(a)(1).
The record, including the FOSC's declaration and supporting materials, establishes that the FOSC made a 'substantial threat' determination and that it was not arbitrary or capricious.
Discovery is unnecessary because the liability determination is based on the administrative record and the FOSC's delegated authority.

issue_1.reasoning: The question is whether the district court applied the correct legal standard in granting summary judgment on liability under OPA § 2702(a). The proper standard for summary judgment is de novo review. The OPA does not expressly delegate to the FOSC the authority to conclusively determine, for purposes of civil liability, whether an incident posed a 'substantial threat of a discharge of oil.' The FOSC's determination may be relevant evidence, but the United States must prove this element by a preponderance of the evidence, not merely by showing the FOSC's decision was not arbitrary or capricious. The district court erred by applying the APA standard rather than requiring the United States to meet its burden under the ordinary civil standard. This error warrants reversal and remand for application of the correct standard and, if necessary, further factual development.

issue_2.reasoning: Statutory standing is a legal question reviewed de novo. The district court did not address whether the United States had the requisite relationship to the natural resources under OPA § 2706(a)(1). The burden is on the United States to show the coral reefs are 'belonging to, managed by, controlled by, or appertaining to the United States.' The record is unclear as to whether the United States meets this requirement, especially given Puerto Rico's asserted exclusive control under the Federal Relations Act. The failure to address this element is reversible error, and the case must be remanded for the district court to make the necessary findings.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Both issues present legal errors in the district court's summary judgment ruling. The court applied the wrong standard to the 'substantial threat' element and failed to address the statutory standing requirement. Both errors require reversal and remand for application of the correct legal standards and further proceedings as necessary. The appellate court is likely to reverse the grant of summary judgment on liability.

parties.appellant: Sonterra Capital Master Fund, Ltd. (plaintiff), Richard Dennis (plaintiff), FrontPoint European Fund L.P. (plaintiff)
parties.appellee: UBS AG (defendant), Barclays Bank PLC (defendant), Cooperative Centrale Raiffeisen-Boerenleenbank B.A. (defendant), Lloyds Banking Group PLC (defendant), The Royal Bank of Scotland PLC (defendant), Barclays Capital Inc. (defendant), John Does 1-50 (defendants), Deutsche Bank AG (defendant)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Plaintiffs, consisting of an individual (Richard Dennis), an investment fund (Sonterra Capital Master Fund, Ltd.), and a limited partnership (FrontPoint European Fund L.P.), traded in derivatives based on the Sterling London Interbank Offered Rate (Sterling LIBOR). Sterling LIBOR is a benchmark interest rate reflecting the average rate at which leading banks can borrow in pounds sterling in London. The rate is calculated by the British Bankers’ Association (BBA) using daily submissions from a panel of sixteen banks, with the middle fifty percent of quotes averaged to produce the official rate. Plaintiffs allege that the defendant banks conspired to manipulate Sterling LIBOR to benefit their trading positions in Sterling LIBOR-based derivatives. The alleged scheme involved traders at the defendant banks requesting their LIBOR submission teams to submit false quotes, with the direction of manipulation (upward or downward) depending on the banks’ trading positions. The manipulation was coordinated both internally and externally among banks, including through inter-dealer brokers. Plaintiffs claim that this conduct was encouraged by senior management, facilitated by organizational changes and lax compliance, and, in the case of Deutsche Bank AG, involved misleading regulators. The alleged manipulation affected the pricing, benchmarking, and settlement of various derivatives, including foreign exchange forwards, futures contracts, and interest-rate swaps.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Plaintiffs filed a putative class action in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, alleging violations of section 1 of the Sherman Act (conspiracy to restrain trade and fix prices), sections 6(c), 9, and 22 of the Commodity Exchange Act (CEA) (manipulation of Sterling LIBOR and related derivatives), the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), and state common-law claims for unjust enrichment and breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court dismissed all of plaintiffs’ claims. It found that Sonterra and Dennis lacked antitrust standing, that FrontPoint no longer had litigating capacity and had not assigned its claims to its would-be substitute (Fund Liquidation Holdings, LLC), and that Dennis failed to plead specific intent for his CEA claims. The court also dismissed the RICO and most state-law claims. After FrontPoint moved to substitute FLH as plaintiff, the court found that FrontPoint had not assigned the relevant claims to FLH and dismissed the last surviving claims.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Plaintiffs appeal the dismissal of their Sherman Act and Commodity Exchange Act claims. The appeal challenges the district court’s findings regarding antitrust standing, the sufficiency of the pleadings for CEA claims, and the denial of substitution for FrontPoint’s claims. UBS cross-appeals.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in finding that Sonterra and Dennis lacked antitrust standing to bring claims under the Sherman Act.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To establish antitrust standing, a plaintiff must show (1) antitrust injury (a special kind of injury resulting from the anticompetitive conduct) and (2) that they are an 'efficient enforcer' of the antitrust laws. The antitrust injury analysis involves a three-step process: identifying the anticompetitive practice, the actual injury alleged, and comparing the anticompetitive effect to the actual injury.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in dismissing Dennis’s Commodity Exchange Act claims for failure to plead specific intent and actual damages.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A CEA plaintiff must plausibly allege (1) that they transacted in at least one commodity contract at a price that was lower or higher than it otherwise would have been absent the defendant’s manipulations, and (2) that the manipulated prices were to the plaintiff’s detriment. The CEA requires a showing of 'actual damages.'

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in denying substitution of Fund Liquidation Holdings, LLC (FLH) for FrontPoint European Fund L.P. as plaintiff for the remaining claims.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Substitution of parties is governed by Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 25(c), which allows substitution if an interest is transferred during the course of litigation. The court must determine whether a valid assignment of claims occurred.

appellant_arguments: Plaintiffs argue that they have antitrust standing because they participated in a market directly affected by the alleged manipulation and suffered injury as a result of artificial prices.

Plaintiffs contend that the complaint sufficiently alleges specific intent and actual damages under the CEA, as they traded in Sterling LIBOR-based derivatives during the period of alleged manipulation.
Plaintiffs assert that FrontPoint’s assignment of claims to FLH was valid and that FLH should have been substituted as plaintiff for the remaining claims.
appellee_arguments: Defendants argue that plaintiffs lack antitrust standing because they did not transact directly with defendants and cannot show that any injury was proximately caused by the alleged conduct.

Defendants contend that plaintiffs failed to allege actual damages or specific transactions in which they suffered harm as a result of the alleged manipulation, and thus fail to state a claim under the CEA.
Defendants maintain that FrontPoint did not validly assign its claims to FLH and that substitution was properly denied.

issue_1.reasoning: Antitrust standing is a question of law reviewed de novo. The Second Circuit and other courts have held that plaintiffs who trade in financial instruments whose prices are directly set or influenced by a manipulated benchmark (like LIBOR) can have antitrust standing, even if they did not transact directly with the defendants. Plaintiffs plausibly allege injury from artificial prices in a market directly affected by the alleged conspiracy. The district court's requirement of direct dealing is too restrictive in the context of benchmark manipulation.

issue_2.reasoning: Dismissal for failure to state a claim is reviewed de novo. The complaint alleges that Dennis traded in Sterling LIBOR-based derivatives during the period of alleged manipulation, and that the manipulation affected the prices of those instruments. Courts have found such allegations sufficient at the pleading stage to allege actual damages and specific intent under the CEA, especially where the manipulation is alleged to be systematic and market-wide.

issue_3.reasoning: Substitution of parties is reviewed for abuse of discretion, but whether a valid assignment occurred is a legal question. The record indicates that FrontPoint did assign its claims to FLH, and the district court's contrary finding appears to be based on an overly technical reading of the assignment documents. The equities favor substitution to allow the real party in interest to pursue the claims.

stage2_decision.reasoning: All three issues are likely to be reversed. The appellate court will find that plaintiffs have antitrust standing because they participated in a market directly affected by the alleged manipulation, that the CEA claims are sufficiently pleaded at this stage, and that substitution of FLH for FrontPoint was improperly denied. The trend in benchmark manipulation cases is to allow such claims to proceed past the pleading stage, and the assignment/substitution issue is likely to be resolved in favor of allowing the claims to be litigated on the merits.

parties.appellant: Hospital Amerimed Cancun S A de C V and Hospital Quirurgica Del Sur, plaintiffs in the district court
parties.appellee: Martin's Point Health Care, Inc., defendant in the district court

stage1_summary.factual_background: Each case began when a Martin's Point Health Care, Inc. enrollee sought medical care from one of the plaintiff hospitals while in Mexico. Upon admission, the enrollees signed contracts obligating them to pay for all services rendered by the admitting hospital and provided information about their Martin's Point medical insurance. The hospitals contacted Martin's Point through a third-party administrator. Martin's Point allegedly represented to the administrator that the enrollees had 'full medical insurance benefits for the ... out of country emergency services proposed to be provided.' The administrator then created verification-of-benefits forms stating that the enrollees' benefits were 'unlimited.' Relying on these representations, the hospitals provided extensive medical treatment to the enrollees. During the hospital stays, Martin's Point sent letters authorizing the stays for several days, but the letters stated that authorization was 'subject to Medicare coding requirements for coverage' and that 'payment [wa]s based on the [enrollee's] eligibility and benefit coverage at the time of service.' Upon discharge, the enrollees had incurred medical bills of $2,132,982.98 and $512,464.00, respectively. The hospitals sought reimbursement from Martin's Point, but Martin's Point asserted that the enrollees' Medicare Advantage plans capped benefits for out-of-country medical services at $25,000 and refused to reimburse the hospitals above that limit.

procedural_history.claims_brought: The hospitals filed separate civil actions in the District of Maine against Martin's Point based on diversity jurisdiction, asserting Maine common-law claims for promissory estoppel and negligent misrepresentation. The claims were based on the premise that Martin's Point misrepresented to the third-party administrator that its enrollees' medical insurance would fully cover the proposed course of treatment, thereby inducing the hospitals to provide non-reimbursable care.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted Martin's Point's motions to dismiss for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, concluding that the hospitals' negligent-misrepresentation and promissory-estoppel claims arose under the Medicare Act and that the hospitals were required to exhaust administrative remedies before suing Martin's Point in federal court. The court also denied the hospitals' subsequent Rule 59(e) motions to alter the judgments of dismissal, in which the hospitals argued that, as foreign hospitals, they could not participate in the Medicare Part C administrative-review process and should be exempt from the exhaustion requirement.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The hospitals appeal the dismissals of their complaints for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and the denials of their Rule 59(e) motions. They challenge the district court's conclusion that their claims arise under the Medicare Act and are subject to administrative exhaustion, and argue that they should be exempt from the exhaustion requirement as foreign hospitals.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the hospitals' common-law claims for promissory estoppel and negligent misrepresentation arise under the Medicare Act, thereby requiring exhaustion of administrative remedies before seeking judicial review.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: A claim arises under the Medicare Act if the standing and the substantive basis for the claim derive from the statute, or if the claim is inextricably intertwined with a Medicare benefits determination. Claims that are wholly collateral to Medicare's review provisions and outside the agency's expertise may not arise under the Act.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the hospitals, as foreign hospitals, are exempt from the Medicare Act's administrative exhaustion requirement because they are unable to participate in the administrative-review process.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Under Illinois Council, administrative exhaustion may not be required if it would mean no review at all, rather than simply channeling review through the agency. The party seeking exemption must show that they are foreclosed from participating in the administrative-review process.

appellant_arguments: The hospitals' claims do not arise under the Medicare Act because the services provided were outside the United States and not covered by Medicare, so the claims are not subject to Medicare's administrative exhaustion requirements.

Even if the claims arise under the Medicare Act, the hospitals should be exempt from the exhaustion requirement because, as foreign hospitals, they cannot participate in the Medicare Part C administrative-review process.
The claims are based on state common law (promissory estoppel and negligent misrepresentation) and seek damages, not Medicare benefits, so they should not be subject to Medicare's jurisdictional bar.
The hospitals are asserting claims in their own right, not as assignees of the enrollees, and the enrollees have no interest in the actions.
appellee_arguments: The hospitals' claims, although styled as common-law causes of action, are in substance claims for reimbursement under the enrollees' Medicare Advantage plans and therefore arise under the Medicare Act.
Because the hospitals have not exhausted their administrative remedies under the Medicare Act, the district court lacks subject-matter jurisdiction over the actions.

The hospitals' status as foreign hospitals does not exempt them from the administrative exhaustion requirement, and they have not shown that they are precluded from participating in the administrative-review process.
Even if the claims were not construed as Medicare-benefits claims, the hospitals' complaints fail to state claims for relief under state law.

issue_1.reasoning: Whether a claim 'arises under' the Medicare Act is a legal question reviewed de novo. The hospitals' claims, though framed as state-law causes of action, are inextricably intertwined with the right to payment under Medicare Advantage plans. The claims depend on the existence and scope of Medicare coverage, and the relief sought (reimbursement) is the same as would be available under the Medicare Act. Precedent (e.g., Heckler v. Ringer, Do Sung Uhm v. Humana, Inc.) supports the conclusion that such claims arise under the Act and are subject to its exhaustion requirements.

issue_2.reasoning: Whether the hospitals are exempt from exhaustion is also a legal question reviewed de novo. Under Illinois Council, exemption is warranted only if there is 'no review at all.' The hospitals have not shown that they are absolutely foreclosed from seeking administrative review; rather, they face procedural obstacles. Courts have generally held that mere difficulty or inconvenience does not excuse exhaustion. The record does not establish that the administrative process is entirely unavailable to foreign hospitals.

stage2_decision.reasoning: Both issues turn on well-settled legal principles. The claims are inextricably intertwined with Medicare benefits determinations and thus arise under the Act, requiring exhaustion. The hospitals have not demonstrated that they are categorically barred from administrative review, only that it may be difficult or impractical. The district court's dismissal for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction and denial of Rule 59(e) relief are therefore likely to be affirmed.

parties.appellant: Angel Tudor, plaintiff (teacher at Whitehall Central School District)
parties.appellee: Whitehall Central School District, defendant (employer/school district)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Angel Tudor has been employed by Whitehall Central School District for approximately 20 years, initially as a substitute teacher and later as a high school math teacher. Tudor suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) stemming from sexual harassment and assault by a supervisor at a previous workplace. Her PTSD symptoms include neurological impairment, difficulty performing daily tasks, a stutter, severe nightmares, and the need for multiple medications and psychiatric care. In 2008, Tudor and her therapist requested and received an accommodation from Whitehall, allowing her to leave campus for a 15-minute break during each of her morning and afternoon prep periods, which helped her manage her symptoms. In 2016, after a change in school administration, Whitehall implemented a policy prohibiting teachers from leaving school grounds during prep periods. Tudor was reprimanded for attempting to take her breaks and was told her documentation was insufficient. She subsequently took paid sick leave and then FMLA leave due to her PTSD. Upon returning in January 2017, Whitehall allowed her a morning break and, when possible, an afternoon break if a librarian could cover her class. This arrangement continued through the 2017-18 and 2018-19 school years. For the 2019-20 school year, Tudor's schedule included a morning prep period and an afternoon study hall, but no staff were available to cover her for an afternoon break. Tudor nonetheless left for breaks during study hall on 91 of 100 days before the COVID-19 pandemic forced remote learning, but did so without explicit authorization and with increased anxiety due to violating school policy.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Tudor filed suit alleging that Whitehall's refusal to guarantee her a 15-minute afternoon break each day during the 2019-20 school year constituted a failure to accommodate under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and New York State law. She later dismissed the state-law claims.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted summary judgment in favor of Whitehall, assuming without deciding that Tudor had a qualifying disability and that Whitehall's scheduling decision was a denial of her requested accommodation. The court found that because Tudor admitted she could perform the essential functions of her job without the accommodation, she could not establish the third element of her failure-to-accommodate claim.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Tudor appeals the district court's grant of summary judgment on her ADA failure-to-accommodate claim, specifically challenging the conclusion that her ability to perform essential job functions without accommodation precluded her claim.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether an employee's ability to perform the essential functions of her job without a reasonable accommodation is fatal to her failure-to-accommodate claim under the ADA.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: To establish a prima facie case for failure to accommodate under the ADA, a plaintiff must show: (1) the employer is subject to the ADA; (2) the plaintiff was disabled within the meaning of the ADA; (3) the plaintiff was otherwise qualified to perform the essential functions of the job, with or without reasonable accommodation; and (4) the employer refused to make a reasonable accommodation. The ADA defines a 'qualified individual' as someone who, with or without reasonable accommodation, can perform the essential functions of the job. Reasonable accommodation includes job restructuring or modified work schedules, unless it would impose an undue hardship on the employer.

appellant_arguments: The ADA entitles qualified employees to reasonable accommodations even if they can perform the essential functions of their job without the accommodation.
The district court misapplied the legal standard by requiring that the accommodation be strictly necessary for job performance, rather than considering whether it was reasonable.
The denial of the requested accommodation caused significant harm and duress, even though Tudor continued to perform her job.
appellee_arguments: Tudor was able to perform the essential functions of her job without the requested accommodation, so she cannot establish a necessary element of her failure-to-accommodate claim.
The accommodation was not required under the ADA because Tudor was not prevented from performing her job duties.
The district court correctly applied the legal standard in granting summary judgment.

issue_1.reasoning: The standard for summary judgment is de novo. The district court erred by holding that an employee's ability to perform essential job functions without accommodation is fatal to a failure-to-accommodate claim. The ADA entitles qualified individuals to reasonable accommodations even if they can perform the essential functions of their job without them, as long as the accommodation is reasonable and not an undue hardship. The plaintiff's ability to perform her job without the accommodation does not preclude her claim if the denial of accommodation caused her significant harm or made her job substantially more difficult. The district court misapplied the legal standard, so summary judgment was inappropriate.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The district court's legal error in requiring that the accommodation be strictly necessary for job performance, rather than considering whether the requested accommodation was reasonable and whether its denial caused harm, is contrary to established ADA precedent. The appellate court is likely to reverse and remand for further proceedings under the correct legal standard.

parties.appellant: New York Football Giants, Inc.; Houston NFL Holdings, L.P., dba Houston Texans; Denver Broncos; National Football League (defendants in the district court)
parties.appellee: Brian Flores, as a class representative on behalf of himself and all others similarly situated (plaintiff in the district court)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Brian Flores is a current NFL coach who has worked for several NFL teams, including the New England Patriots, Miami Dolphins, Pittsburgh Steelers, and Minnesota Vikings. In January 2019, while under contract with the Patriots, Flores interviewed for the head coach position with the Denver Broncos but was not hired, allegedly due to racial discrimination. In January 2022, after being fired as head coach of the Miami Dolphins, Flores interviewed for head coach positions with the New York Giants and Houston Texans but was not hired by either, again allegedly due to racial discrimination and retaliation. Flores subsequently accepted a coaching position with the Pittsburgh Steelers. The NFL is an unincorporated association of 32 member clubs, governed by the NFL Constitution and Bylaws, which grants the NFL Commissioner broad authority, including the power to arbitrate disputes between coaches and member clubs.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Flores, along with other plaintiffs, brought a putative class action against the NFL and several member clubs, including the Denver Broncos, New York Giants, Miami Dolphins, and Houston Texans, alleging racial discrimination under 42 U.S.C. § 1981 and related state and local statutes. The operative complaint also included claims by Steve Wilks and Ray Horton against other NFL teams.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted the motion to compel arbitration for Flores's claims against the Miami Dolphins, Wilks's claims against the Arizona Cardinals, and Horton's claims against the Tennessee Titans, as well as related claims against the NFL. However, the court denied the motion to compel arbitration for Flores's claims against the Denver Broncos, New York Giants, Houston Texans, and related claims against the NFL, finding the relevant arbitration provisions unenforceable or not properly executed.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: The NFL, Denver Broncos, New York Giants, and Houston Texans appealed the district court's denial of their motion to compel arbitration of Flores's claims against the Broncos, Giants, Texans, and related claims against the NFL, as well as the denial of their motion for reconsideration.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred by denying arbitration of Flores’s claims against the Denver Broncos and the NFL based on his employment agreement with the New England Patriots, which incorporated by reference the NFL Constitution.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Whether a valid and enforceable arbitration agreement exists under the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) and applicable state law; whether the agreement allows for effective vindication of statutory rights.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in denying the motion to compel arbitration of Flores’s claims against the New York Giants, Houston Texans, and the NFL, based on his employment agreement with the Pittsburgh Steelers.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Whether a valid and enforceable arbitration agreement exists under the FAA and applicable state law; whether the agreement was properly executed and applies to the claims at issue.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion by denying the defendants’ motion for reconsideration after they submitted a signed copy of the Flores-Steelers agreement.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: Abuse of discretion standard for denial of motions for reconsideration.

appellant_arguments: Flores’s employment agreements with the Patriots and Steelers, which incorporate the NFL Constitution, require arbitration of his claims against the Broncos, Giants, Texans, and the NFL.
The NFL is entitled to enforce the arbitration agreements under the doctrine of equitable estoppel, as the claims against the NFL are factually intertwined with those against the member clubs.
The district court erred in finding the arbitration provision illusory or unenforceable, and in relying on the absence of the NFL Commissioner’s signature on the Steelers agreement.
appellee_arguments: The arbitration provision in the NFL Constitution is unenforceable because it gives the NFL Commissioner, an interested party, unilateral authority over both the substance and procedure of the arbitration, lacking independence and fairness.
The agreement fails to guarantee effective vindication of statutory rights, as required under federal law.
The Steelers agreement was not validly executed at the time of the district court’s decision, and the district court properly denied reconsideration.

issue_1.reasoning: The enforceability of the arbitration agreement under the FAA is reviewed de novo. The district court found the arbitration provision in the NFL Constitution unenforceable as applied to Flores’s claims against the Broncos and NFL, primarily because the NFL Commissioner, who would serve as arbitrator, is not a neutral party and the process lacks sufficient procedural safeguards. Recent appellate and Supreme Court cases have recognized that arbitration agreements may be unenforceable if they do not provide a fair forum or effective vindication of statutory rights. Given the Commissioner’s dual role as employer and arbitrator, and the lack of meaningful neutrality, the district court’s conclusion is likely to be upheld.

issue_2.reasoning: The district court denied arbitration of Flores’s claims against the Giants, Texans, and NFL based on the Steelers agreement, finding the agreement was not properly executed (lacking the Commissioner’s signature) and that the arbitration provision was unenforceable for the same reasons as in issue 1. The appellate court will review de novo whether a valid agreement existed and whether it is enforceable. The lack of execution at the time of the district court’s decision and the same concerns about fairness and effective vindication support affirmance.

issue_3.reasoning: The district court’s denial of reconsideration is reviewed for abuse of discretion. The NFL submitted a signed copy of the Steelers agreement only after the district court’s ruling. Courts generally do not abuse their discretion by refusing to reconsider based on evidence that could have been presented earlier, especially when the underlying legal issue (enforceability of the arbitration provision) remains unchanged. Thus, affirmance is likely.

stage2_decision.reasoning: The district court’s reasoning is consistent with recent case law scrutinizing the fairness of employer-controlled arbitration, especially where the arbitrator is not neutral and the process may not allow for effective vindication of statutory rights. The procedural issues regarding execution of the agreement and the timing of evidence submission further support affirmance. The abuse of discretion standard on reconsideration is highly deferential. Therefore, the appellate court is likely to affirm on all issues.

parties.appellant: Alexandra E. Melino, plaintiff (former employee, registered nurse at Boston Medical Center)
parties.appellee: Boston Medical Center, defendant (former employer)

stage1_summary.factual_background: Alexandra Melino began working as a registered nurse in the Cardiac Intensive Care Unit (CCU) at Boston Medical Center (BMC) in 2014. Her duties included providing direct care to critically ill patients and coordinating with their families, working alongside physicians, other nurses, and nursing assistants. During the COVID-19 pandemic, BMC converted several units, including the CCU, into COVID-19 units to handle a surge of seriously ill patients. Between January 2020 and July 2021, BMC treated over 3,200 COVID-19 patients and experienced significant staff shortages due to infections among healthcare workers. BMC determined that healthcare providers were at increased risk of contracting and spreading COVID-19, especially to medically vulnerable patients, and that increased transmission risk could negatively impact its ability to provide critical care. Following CDC recommendations, BMC implemented a policy on August 21, 2021, requiring all employees and volunteers to be vaccinated against COVID-19, with provisions for medical or religious exemptions. Melino requested a religious exemption but did not provide additional information when asked and did not seek any accommodation short of a complete exemption. BMC denied her request, and after she did not comply with the vaccination requirement, her employment was terminated on October 15, 2021.

procedural_history.claims_brought: Melino filed suit against BMC alleging violations of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act and Massachusetts General Laws ch. 151B, claiming BMC unlawfully denied her request for a religious exemption to the COVID-19 vaccine mandate.
procedural_history.district_court_decision: The district court granted summary judgment to BMC, finding that Melino's requested exemption would have imposed undue hardship on BMC. The court also denied Melino's motion to strike portions of an affidavit submitted by BMC.
procedural_history.what_is_appealed: Melino appeals the grant of summary judgment in favor of BMC and the denial of her motion to strike portions of BMC's affidavit.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in granting summary judgment to BMC on the grounds that accommodating Melino's request for a religious exemption would impose an undue hardship on the employer.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: 'Undue hardship' under Title VII is shown when a burden is substantial in the overall context of an employer's business. The employer bears the burden of proving undue hardship, and courts must consider all relevant factors, including the nature, size, and operating cost of the employer, and the practical impact of the requested accommodation.

issues_on_appeal.description: Whether the district court erred in denying Melino's motion to strike portions of BMC's affidavit that referenced CDC recommendations as inadmissible hearsay.
issues_on_appeal.legal_standard: District courts have broad discretion in administering local rules, including requirements for conferring before filing motions (Local Rule 7.1(a)(2)). Hearsay objections are evaluated under Federal Rule of Evidence 801(c), and statements offered to show the effect on the listener or to explain motive are not hearsay.

appellant_arguments: BMC failed to prove that the COVID-19 vaccines actually prevent recipients from catching and spreading COVID-19, and thus failed to establish undue hardship.
The district court improperly relied on BMC's affidavit referencing CDC recommendations, which Melino argued was inadmissible hearsay.
Melino argued that the evidence regarding vaccine efficacy was insufficient and that there were disputes of material fact regarding the effectiveness of the vaccines.
Melino contended that the district court should have considered whether alternative accommodations, short of a complete exemption, were possible.
appellee_arguments: BMC implemented its vaccine requirement based on CDC recommendations and scientific evidence that vaccination reduces the risk of COVID-19 transmission and protects patients and staff.
